Stress the "Marunouchi" part and make sure to watch where they're going. Carry a hotel card with you to hand to the driver. I would recommend this hotel to everyone going to Tokyo and I would definitely stay here again.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Just came back from my 5th trip to Tokyo. This is my second time at the Four Season Marunouchi, and they provide an amazing experience. My wife and I go to Tokyo, as it is our favorite city in the world, and the Four Seasons makes it easy to be in a city that some find quite extreme.Pick up service at Tokyo Station - You get off your flight in Narita, buy your Narita Express ticket, call the hotel up with your train number, car and seat. 45 minutes later your train arrive in Tokyo Station, and a bell staff is waiting at your train to assist with your luggage and to navigate you through the complexity of the station. They do the same service on the way back. What a pleasure.Since they know you are on a train, your check-in is flawless, and everything is ready for you, with someone waiting to bring you to your room.We've never had a bad view, but since the rooms are only up to the 6th floor of the building, look out and watch what appear to be the most organized ants going to work in the morning.Breakfast is a treat (a bit expensive, but this is the Four Seasons, so it's expected). However, everyone knows who you are, remembers what you had the day before, and brings you that extra cup of hot water for your tea, without even asking for it.Room Service - Took about 30 minutes, not too bad. But get this, the food cart has a warming part, and your food is HOT when it arrives.One night we arrived back in our room with a bottle of champagne and berries, as a thank you. Now, I would assume not everyone gets this, but it was greatly appreciated.There are umbrellas at the front door, bikes to borrow if you want to be adventurous (or just ride around the Imperial Gardens), and the door staff always knows your name, and makes sure you had a good day, typically escorting you to the elevator.Only 57 rooms, that are quite large by Tokyo standards. Very comfortable linens, multiple robes, pajamas, tea service, electric bidet/toilet, large tub, and separate shower.The hotel is just a special place.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Excellent service, good quality rooms. Expensive (ish) but its Tokyo

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Stayed for 4 nights during a business trips. The service was excellent: very personal, making you feel at home. But even better, where the beds. It was my first time in Tokyo, and the Four Seasons made it easy diving into such a great city. I will definitely go back next time I am in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The most wonderful aspect of staying at the Four Seasons at Marunouchi is that it feels like you are staying at home. The Park Hyatt may be more imposing and have an unequalled zen-like atmosphere but for quiet relaxation and a home away from home, you can't beat this hotel. The rooms are great; well appointed, spotlessly clean, comfortable and inviting. the Wi-fi is lightning fast and it is easy to use. Room service is prompt and the food is excellent. Most of all it is the quiet, personal and warm service that makes the Four Seasons stand out. No request is too big or too small and the smiling faces are a welcome end to a busy work day. If given the choice between the Park Hyatt and The Four Seasons at Marunouchi I know where I will be ... back in my personal haven at Pacific Century Place ... The Four Seasons.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Amazing... from Soup to Nuts. I can not say enough about this beautiful hotel. There is special service to the train where the staff escorts you to the platform. Perfect room, clean, renovated and GORGEOUS!!!!!! WORTH EVERY PENNY and then an extra dime. WONDERFUL JAPANESE BREAKFAST. A DREAM.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Our family has stayed at various Four Seasons properties and has always found the product to be superior. However the Four Seasons Tokyo and Marunouchi even exceeded our high expectations and is perhaps our new favorite property.The small scale of the hotel allows for extremely personal service. We were traveling with our 7-year-old daughter and felt that the staff sincerely enjoyed meeting her and talking to her. Not JUST her, we were all made to feel very welcome and even special but the way our daughter was welcomed was exceptional. The hotel had cookies for her in our room, small-scale robe and slippers, bath toys etc. Small touches that collectively really added up to mean a lot.At one point we asked about which bullet train to take for a day trip and a member of the staff not only walked us to the station and ordered the tickets for us (in Japanese) but then purchased a ticket for himself so that he may enter the station and walk us all the way to the actual train making sure that we were all set and on our way. Later when it was time to check out another member of the staff walked us (and all of our luggage) to the terminal for the bus to the airport, waiting at the station until we actually pulled away. This type of service in invaluable and extremely helpful.A very welcome and unexpected surprise was an upgraded room to a spectacular suite... The entire (all too short) stay was flawless and wonderful.Earlier this same trip we had stayed at the Peninsula. While this is also a spectacular hotel the simple fact is that the Four Seasons is superior (for us anyway). The room was nicer (and that is saying something) the service was perfect and the location is nearly ideal. These are pros running a tight ship and I cannot recommend them more highly.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Until our recent stay at The Four Seasons Tokyo at Maranouchi we have compared all hotels to the Four Season George V in Paris, where we have had top notch service, food and amazing stays. That standard of servise has now been blown out of the water by the staff at the Four Seasons Tokyo at Maranouchi.Is the hotel beautiful, comfortable and in a great location? Is the food nice? All these things were true about this hotel, but it does not speak to the best service we have ever experienced. I should preface this by saying we arrived in Tokyo after spending 6 weeks on The Crystal Serenity cruise ship. We had been pampered and attended to by some of the best in the hospitality industry. This stay equaled and in many ways exceeded the service we had recieved on the ship. And it came down to the people employed at this extraordinary hotel.Two examples: Our daughter had flown in from Los Angeles to stay and see Tokyo with us. She wanted to go to the Studion Ghibli museum, and we agreed. To buy tickets we needed to go across the street to a kiosk inside a convenience store. The bellstaff gave us detailed information before we set out for the store to buy tickets. However when we got there we reached an impass when we couldn't operate the machine correctly. My husband went back to the hotel and asked for help. Immediately one of the staff came back with him, helped us get the tickets and then walked us several blocks to a subways staion to get to our destination. When we returned from our day's adventure, whoever was at the bell desk would address us by name, and ask how our visit to "____" was, as they knew what we were doing on a daily basis.The second and most personally touching moment for me during our stay was when my husband had a medical problem that necessitated a visit the St. Luke's Medical Center. When we go into the taxi, and looked out the window on our way to the hospital there were 3 or more employees bowing and wishing us well. When we go to the emergency room a Dr. greeted us and took us to the registration counter and paved the way for us to communicate in english. I attribute the care we recieved at the hospital to the staff at the Four Seasons. Thank you so much.Several people have mentioned the restaurant in the hotel, and I want to recommend the breakfast there. It is, like most things in Tokyo expensive but so worht it. The breakfast starts with an amuse bouche yogurt drink, and the pastries were very good, as was everything else.Bravo to the staff and management. You have set the bar high. I cann't imagine another hotel exceeding the service you have provided.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: This is a very clean, well styled and appointed, low key boutique hotel in the heart of Tokyo. If you are looking for the "big hotel" experience, this is not it. If you are looking for an excellent, quiet more personal experience in a very Western friendly hotel, this is for you. I was there for business, but there were families staying as well. It is great for both.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We had a great stay. The rooms are very comfortable. The staff is extremely helpful. The service is impeccable.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The FSH Tokyo at Marunouchi is a superb little hotel with a fantastic location. Located steps away from the Tokyo Train Station, the hotel is within easy walking distance of both the Ginza Shopping District and the Imperial Palace. The Tsukiji Fish Market is either a 10-minute cab ride or about an hour walk away.The rooms are big (especially by Tokyo standards) and well equipped. They have a modern, clean (slightly minimalist) design, with lots of light and great views train station. Don't worry, the trains are not noisy and it is fun to watch the bullet trains pull into and out of the train station. Basic internet services for one device is included in the hotel rate. Connectivity was easy and download speeds from websites were ok. It took about 4 minutes to download the most recent issue of the Economist. The hotel's only restaurant (ekki Bar & Grill) was very good. I had an excellent dinner there. There are tons of places to eat at all price categories within easy walking distance of the hotel.The service levels are great. The front door, front desk and concierge staff are all very helpful. Local travel arrangements were made much easier with their assistance (especially Japanese instructions to taxi drivers and train ticket agents) and restaurant suggestions were great. Take advantage of the hotel's platform greeting: the Tokyo Train Station is quite large, and if you are a little groggy from a long flight, it is easy to take a wrong step.A few tips:1. FSH instructs you to take the "Yaesu South Exit". As you get off the train from the airport, there are only Yaesu Central and Yaesu North signs. Follow the "Yaesu Central Exit" signs until you see the "Yaesu South Exit" signs. And if you happen to miss them, no big deal: the Yaesu Central Exit will take you were you need to be (you still turn right when you reach the main street).2. Taxi's are widely available and are exceptionally clean. The driver has a switch to automatically open and close the passenger door. They are a bit expensive but not overly so. Most don't speak any English so have your Japanese destination instructions with you and be sure to have return instructions for the hotel.3. Definitely go to the Tsukiji Fish Market. And you don't need to get up at 4:00 am. While I missed the auction, I went down about 8:30 am and saw lots of action in the inner market. Also, it is unbelievably clean with no "fish smell" at all. Great sushi is available in the outer market. All-in-all, very impressive!4. Kamakura, about an hour from Tokyo by train, is a great place to visit for the day. It is a quant little village with about 15 shrines and temples within close proximity. It is a great place to walk and english signage makes it easy to get from one temple to the next. Please note that the station immediately before "Kamakura" is "Kita-Kamakura". You can get off at either station though "Kamakura" is at the centre of the town.5. Excellent ramen noodles at "Ippudo" in the nearby Marunouchi Brick Square. (This was recommended by the hotel.)

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: This was our second time at this Four Seasons and it was as great the the first one.The rooms are spaciuos, the service perfect. Room service is avalaible 24h and very high quality. Minibar has all you need and water is complimentary.You can get a comlimentary greeting welcome at the Narita station where personel from the hotel will meet you and take you and your luggage to the hotel.Breackfast is a la carte, no buffet.The sap doesn't have a manicure service, only massage.The hotel is in the heart of Ginza. Always a great stay.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I can't imagine a more perfect place to have stayed during our first trip to Tokyo. As other reviewers have said, staying at the Four Seasons Marunouchi feels like coming home. It is an oasis of warmth, comfort and personal attention in the biggest city in the world. The staff is kind, warm and incredibly helpful with everything from transportation to restaurant reservations, and even explanations of the local culture. My wife and I had many long conversations with staff members to ask for help with various things, and they never once made us feel rushed or that we were taking them away from more important things. During the middle of our trip, we left the city for a few days to see Kyoto and Hakone, and when we returned everyone remembered where we had gone and asked about our trip. One of the best services they offer is meeting you at the train station and walking you to the hotel. It's a wonderful way to arrive in the city. When it was time for us to leave Tokyo and take the train back out to the airport, Kaye walked us all the way to our train, made sure we got on the right car, and then didn't leave until our train took off. Our last memory of Tokyo was looking out our train window to see a wonderful member of the Four Seasons staff waving us goodbye. We hope to get to Tokyo again one day soon, and will definitely stay there again.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We were met at the train station after a ski trip in northern Japan by a representative of the hotel. She was there with a cart to take our skis and escort us to the hotel. What a great service and at no charge. The staff were very attentive. The location is centralized to many tourist spots. The rooms are large, modern, and very comfortable.The Concierge arranged a 4wd car for our ski trip before we arrived in Japan. We were unable to find a 4wd car on are own. The staff were equally helpful when we arrived at the hotel.This is my second time that I stayed at this hotel and would do it again.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Convenient to train station, shopping and the Imperial Gardens, excellent attentive service (possibly the best I have had in this price range or lower), modern, clean, beautiful rooms. Made for a wonderful stay.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We stayed at the hotel for 4 nights in February 2012. From checkin to checkout we had a wonderful stay. The Manager, Daniel Simon, was there to greet us upon arrival! Having been to Tokyo several times I am used to expecting smaller rooms. We were upgraded to an executive suite which was simply impressive in décor and amenities. The AV system is very modern (built in) and we used both the living room and AV systems to play our music and watch a movie from our iPad on the large flat screen TV. A super nice touch is that all the cords you need are provided.The bathroom area was well stocked with L’Occitane toiletries of every kind and not the tiny little bottles which only last 1 night either. Deep soaker tub, separate shower and spacious walkin closet in the bathroom area. Service was impeccable – not once did we ever see a housekeeping cart or even a door open for cleaning during our stay. Staff always greeted us by name and speaking English was not an issue at all.They have a Nespresso machine in the room with a frother. A really nice touch is they include a container of milk in the fridge – forget tiny creamers or the like. The Nespresso pods were always replenished – even the milk during our stay! Turndown service always occurred without request. The staff were helpful at every encounter. Bottles of water are included at the bedside (there is nothing more annoying than a 5 star hotel charging for bottled water in the room!)A very nice touch is that the 1F entrance has a Jura machine for making coffee/cappuccino as well as juices in the mornings. The gym has several treadmills, free weights and lots of fixed machines. The fitness room is located in the spa and one can use the locker rooms, as well as showers/steam room and onsen in the locker rooms. Again – wonderful amenities and nice lockers.We had our room facing Tokyo station and I agree with other reviews, this is not a negative as watching the trains come and go was very enjoyable – and the floor to ceiling double paned windows kept out any noise.The small number of rooms – 57 in total – really makes this hotel a winner. Everything feels so personal and intimate. Quiet elegant luxury. Well worth the price – a home away from home in Tokyo.We did not eat in the restaurant so can not comment on it. We did have a wonderful meal at Tateru Yoshino in Ginza.The location adjacent to Tokyo Station can not be beat for connections to Narita, and travel outside of Tokyo. We used both the subway and train.Hint – buy the Suica + N’Ex pass from the JR ticket office when you arrive at Narita. You get quite a savings on the Narita ticket (available only to foreign visitorss) and the Suica is much more convenient than buying tickets

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: clean n brilliant hotel, nice n detail-minded staff, def. recommend the stay, esp the superior king room overlooking the tokyo station!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: What do you seek in Marunouchi? The heart of the business in Japan is in front of me. Mitsubishi head office functions, SMBC, Hitachi, typical of Japanese companies are concentrated. Ginza, Japan's upscale commercial district, Traditional Culture of Japanese, Kabuki can see in Ginza. Tsukiji where is many sushi restaurant fish market is one of the most famous in the world. Akihabara is no need to explain. Everything is within 2 kilometers. Hotel's location is in front of Tokyo station. There is only 15-minute by train ride to Disneyland. Business? Tourism? Elegant stay? I think all will come true. It is a amazing place. This is THE MARUNOUCHI.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Due to weather we missed our connecting flight from Tokyo to Singapore and consequently had to spend almost a full day in Tokyo beginning with our arrival at Haneda at 1am. Fortunately I had booked the Four Seasons before leaving San Francisco. When we arrived at the Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi we were greeted warmly by the hotel representative who took our bags, handled the check in and escorted us to our room. After getting several hours of rest we had a great breakfast at the hotel and ended up talking with Dan Simon, The General Manager, who after learning of our unplanned visit to Tokyo, offered some suggestions on what to see and took us to talk with the concierge. Mr. Simon extended our check out to 6pm as we had an 11:35pm flight to Singapore. We spent the day seeing the Imperial Gardens, walking through Ginza and seeing Sensoji Temple. Hotel staff was fantastic and we ended up having a memorable visit thanks to the Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Great location for a hotel for business travellers. this Four seasons property is so un assuming that you will miss it even if you walk past the front gate. Once you are in its very sleek , stylish and welcoming. As everything in tokyo it was expensive. The staff is helpful and they are a good conceirge who helps in restaurant bookings etc. I will stay here again next time I am in tokyo,

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: There are a lot of hotels that wow you with glamourous foyers, invisible edge pools and multiple dining choices. The true measure in my eyes is the service culture - and FS Marunouchi has one of the best I've ever experienced. It is clear the employees have pride in their hotel and so they should. The rooms are small in number but exceptional in standard. The single restaurant is simply outstanding so there is no need for a second one - full marks to Gerard's team.(although the breakfast music did make us try to pick the tune from pre 70's middle class America...)Jonathon at Concierge is a great front man - by the time he's picked you up from the train and led you to your room you know the stay is looking good. He's funny, helpful and completely focused on what you want from Tokyo.The rest of the team don't disappoint. They don't want you in the rain without an umbrella, in the lift unless they can press the floor button, on a lounge chair without at least a glass of water or on the subway without one of their own easy to follow printed maps. (and, yes, they will walk you to the station if your unsure)This hotel does have other bonuses. (I almost feel like saying "but wait there's more...")It's so central it could be nicknamed "Bullseye". On top of the main train station with it's underground shopping centre, the hotel is just minutes from the Ginza district, the Imperial Palace and gardens, a short 20 minute trek to the fish markets and in close proximity to the subway system.My family think like I do, and it would seem like a lot of other reviews, this is a lay down choice for Tokyo. Well done FSM!!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We had very pleasant experience with the hotel and staff. The staff service was good and prompt. "All" spoke good English. They took time to note my son's birthday on his passport that coincided with the trip and the staff took time to wait till we arrived back at the room late at night to surprise him with a cake. Nice touch.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Having never been to Tokyo before and not speaking the language, staying at the Fours Seasons Marunouchi made for an easy transition. The hotel staff pick you up from your train car at Tokyo Station after your bullet train ride in from Narita Airport and guide you through the massive and confusing labyrinth that is the train station. The hotel itself is charming and walking distance to the Imperial Palace gardens and the shopping in Ginza. The subway is next door and an easy way to get around the city and see the other areas of interest. We availed ourselves of the concierge to secure tickets for the Sumo tournament, dinner reservations and for guided tours. The service at the hotel was impeccable, even exceeding my prior stays with the Four Seasons hotels. Highly recommended!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel, in terms of superb location, top quality service, friendly warm and hospitable staff and overall "feel good" experience.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We just overnighted here a few days ago, after staying here about a year and a half ago. Like this hotel a lot. Feels much more intimate than most Tokyo hotels. Service is above and beyond. We were personally escorted through the labyrinth of the Tokyo Station to find our way to the Narita express train. They also did not blink when we requested a later than usual check out time. Staff EXTREMELY helpful! Rooms are very large and well appointed. Bed very comfie by Japanese standards. All in all, all you can hope for in a big city hotel.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I feel that that most of the previous reviews fairly represent the hotel and my own experiences earlier this month, though of course tastes differ – particularly with food and service. I was in Asia on a mileage run to maintain that all-important 1K level on United for 2012.Overview:This hotel is the smallest Four Seasons (FS) property that I have ever visited and probably the smallest in the chain. The one FS that I have the most experience is with the Istanbul-Sultanahmet property and this hotel has only 65 rooms. Ergo, the Marunouchi property is not a typical FS. The hotel is indeed a boutique property - meaning it has only 50+ rooms, one restaurant and the staff consistently addressed me by name. It is located in an office building - with its own entrance but not well marked - and next to Tokyo Station (which, of course, is great for the Narita Express). The spa and gym facility is small but so is the hotel, and I rarely encountered another guest in the spa or the gym. I loved the onsen and used it three separate times to sort out a bad back. Incidentally, during my three uses of the onsen, it was my private bath since I never saw another person. Room:I did receive an upgrade to a junior suite (room 506) which overlooked the train station, but the train noise was inaudible and I enjoyed watching the trains arrive and depart. The bathroom was large with a separate bath and shower, and toilet was in true Japanese tradition - you needed a PhD to figure out all the buttons. The bathroom amenities were "standard" FS - l'Occitane. One reviewer complained about the difficulty using some of the room's gadgets but I had no such problem with the two TVs and the window curtain, though I remained puzzled about the toilet (don’t worry – there is a handle). There was also an upscale coffee machine in the roomDining:I did not have room service or breakfast in the hotel. Dinner was very good and cheaper than the $200 meal the next night - but just as good. I did take the free morning coffee and pastry on the ground floor, which I think is served until 8:00am. The lounge is divided into two parts - smoking and non-smoking - and both overlook the train station. The restaurant is non-smoking. I despise smoking but this is par for the course in Japan, and seemed less of a problem at this FS. I met the new F&B manager, who is a Japanese-speaking Aussie. Highlights:My experience with the onsen was already noted. I took the FS bicycle around Tokyo with no problem, with the exception that the helmet was too small – even for my bald head. I enjoyed the Japanese reaction seeing a "gringo" riding around the streets of Tokyo. By far the best experience was having the hotel’s general manager – Daniel Simon – provide me with a personal tour of the Tokyo fish market … at 5:00am. I had a couple of chats previously with Mr. Simon when he was the hotel manager in Sydney but this act was far beyond any service that I have ever experienced at any FS hotel – and I considered it exceptional, even by FS’s legendary standards. While you should not expect a personal tour of the fish market from the GM at 5:00am, it indicates the type of service that you should expect. Lessons Learned in Tokyo:- Carry cash. Many places do not accept credit cards and bank ATMs – even those of major international Japanese banks – did not seem to accept US ATM cards. The post office ATMs did accept my two US ATM cards.- Take advantage of the complimentary FS “greeting” service offered upon arrival at Tokyo Station. I did not. I was confused leaving the train station, which was made worse since it was at rush hour. Also don’t be cheap … take the Narita Express for a few extra bucks instead of the local train.- Anywhere I went I had the hotel write in Japanese my destination and/or exactly what I wanted – such as kabuki tickets. I found English proficiency limited, even amongst the young. This is not Hong Kong. Language was never a problem at the hotel, but particularly when the Japanese-American woman from Chicago was working at the lobby entrance. - After a day I figured out the convoluted Tokyo subway/underground system but never could figure what priced ticket I needed. I just paid the minimum fare and then paid the difference upon exiting the station – no penalty.- Tokyo is an expensive city.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: One of the world's most welcoming, gracious and comforting hotel experiences in a spectacular, flawless facility.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: After staying at two service apartments from our previous visits to Tokyo, we decided to "upgrade" and shoot for the stars. Four Seasons Tokyo on Marunouchi was our choice - close to Tokyo station as we had to come in from Narita, and central to many subway lines, plus who could refuse Four Seasons hospitality.We called ahead while on the NEX (Narita Express) to Tokyo, and we were met by the concierge right at outside our carriage. Jonathon navigated us through the maze of Tokyo station and on our way to the hotel, we met with the new BMW i8 concept car direct from the Tokyo motorshow!Our room was on the 6th floor, and straight away our son was spoilt. They gave him a choice of toy or cup, and in the room, the was a cookie plate with m&m's and marshmallows. Our room was sizable by Japanese standards and the most comfortable. Big comfy king sized bed, and a huge tv that we could connect our Apple devices to. A big plus for the young boy! The son woo and wowed at the size of the toilet (large). Toiletries were from l'occitane and the toilet was glass separated by glass partitions in order of toilet, bath tub installed width wise, and the shower. Very nice!All staff spoke English really well, and usually with an American accent. They were also very helpfully, and would make sure we were given information we asked for.The gym is a good complement to the facilities and there is a mapped run to the nearby Imperial Palace and back. I was going for a morning run, but alas, it was raining.The nearby Tokyo station offered lots to eat- ramen, curries and sushi. There is even a Daimaru department store nearby.We certainly enjoyed our stay here and would love to come back again. We were comfortable and well-loved by all the warm and friendly staff.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: This was our first stop on a trip through Japan and it was great. The location is fabulous, you can walk to and from the train station, and to a lot of ares of Tokyo. Tons of shopping and restaurants very close by. We never needed a cab at all. Our room was great with views of the city. Everyone told us to be aware of the tiny rooms in Japan but our was very large and has a wall of windows. The bathroom was also very nice. We have breakfast in the room each day and it was fabulous, get the Japanese breakfast for sure! There is a large desk area in the room for working as well. The gym is small but nice with great views. The do have hot Japanese baths in the gym for soaking but no pool, we were there in summer and a pool or at least cool dipping pool would have been nice. Not sure if all rooms look over the city, so ask for one just to be sure. Service was also wonderful, everyone there is very helpful, they walked us back to the train station to make sure we went to the right entrance. They will help you with maps of the city and reservations and suggestions on where to go and the best route. Just ask!.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: This hotel is amazing! Not only is it adjacent to the train station, but the client service is over the top. Our first trip to Tokyo was "uneventful" because of the eloquent staff at this hotel. They met us at the train station and walked us to the hotel and when we departed, they did the same thing. I am convinced that this shaved at least 1 hour off of our schedule (because I am sure we would have gotten lost left to our own devices). The rooms were magnifecetn, clean and to our surprise HUGE. Recommendations for restaurants were also spot on.If you have the opportunity to stay here for either business or travel, please give it a try!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: My wife and I have just spent 2 nights at this Hotel. We were on a 'whirl-wind' trip to Japan for the first time. Our destinations were Tokyo and Kyoto. Our first night in Tokyo was at the Four Seasons. We then went on to Kyoto and returned after 3 days in Kyoto to Tokyo and spent our second stay at the Four Seasons.Well words fail me!! This is without doubt the best Hotel from all aspects, service, cleanliness, location, rooms and value for money.We landed at Tokyo Narita airport at about 7am, negotiated the Airport and managed to get the Narita Express to Tokyo Railway Station. Fortunately the Four Seasons has instructions on their web site on what exit to get at Tokyo Railway Station and which way to turn (LOL) and instructions on how to get to the Hotel. Fully armed with these details we managed to find the correct exit (Yaesu South Exit - But Yaesu Central will do equally well) and turned right and after a few minutes walk saw the entry to the hotel.As you enter you we encountered Japanese Hospitality for the first time. In the ground floor entry there is a concierge desk, we reported in (this was about 9am) knowing we were far too early for formal check-in we left our bags with the concierge and went out for a morning stroll (armed with our map) to explore the local surroundings and get some breakfast. The concierge was most apologetic we were not able to check-in immediately and they could not have been more helpful in looking after us for these first few minutes.We returned later in the day to the hotel, and as we entered the ground floor concierge area we were welcomed by name! Very impressive. We were escorted to the reception desk on Level 7 and did the usual check-in things. Again we were formally addressed by name. Our luggage had been put into the room for us and we had been upgraded to the most splendid room on level 6.I had my customary Gin and Tonic when on holiday and the service was outstanding (again called me by name - how do they know that? My belief is that the staff are trained to memorise names and faces, just going one step further than any other hotel chain we have stayed in.)We slept like babies and then enjoyed a delightful breakfast in the ekki bar and grill - food perfect!Then we had to check out. As we were travelling to our next stop in Kyoto I asked the concierge about how to get the Shinkensan. Well that started a frenzy of activity and we were royally escorted to the station by a member of the Four Seasons staff who expertly took care of all the bookings and seat reservations for use. She even saw us to the correct carriage explaining how the doors all line up and the various carriage numbers and where they align with the platform. This young girl was great she even struggled with our luggage for us. Well and above the call of duty I thought!!When we returned to the Four Seasons a few days later we were again met with wonderful friendly smiles and called by name (these were genuine smiles and a genuine welcome back - most welcoming!)Again we were given a wonderful room with tremendous facilities. Again we had to book seats on the Narita Express for our return trip to the airport. We mentioned this to the concierge desk who said 'leave us your information and it will be done overnight' and it was!! We picked up the tickets the next morning and again escorted to the railway station and ushered onto the train.We both enjoyed are brief stays at the Four Seasons and because of the experience we have agreed to return to Tokyo for a longer stay. We will be staying at the Four Seasons during our next visit. In fact we will be utilising the Four Seasons on other forth coming trips as we have been converted by the experience of this stay.Staff were absolutely wonderful; nothing was too much trouble for them - my thanks!!Rooms and all the facilities were excellent of the highest quality.I strongly urge visitors to Tokyo to stay at this hotel.Four Seasons - Domo Arigato

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: actually it is the only Four Seasons I like. But it was a pleasure to stay there again after a long break, when I stayed elsewhere in Tokyo. Interestingly, rather like the Metropolitan in Bangkok, which is about the same vintage, very little has changed in the place, no fancy refurbs or the like. But such is the quality of the design, layout and fittings, it doesn't need to. And superbly run - imagine normal attentive Japanese service - and multiple by ten. Still have to pinch myself it is a Four Seasons............

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Well, my favorite that is not on a beach. It just is the best whether you are in Tokyo on business or pleasure. The location, decoration/design and staff are exceptional. Good central transportation and food with two minutes walking. Ginza glows down the street. Plus watching those trains come and go is fun!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I didn't stay there. It's only 1 hr Keiyo-line ride from home.I tried ekki bar & grill, the only restaurant there.It was Saturday so they had weekend brunch only, which I didn't intend to have, the price was over my budget. So I asked for a la carte menus, took a loot at and ordered sea-urchin pasta, priced 2400jpy (w/10% service charge). It was superb!I've never seen that much sea urchin on one plate for a person. More sea urchin was on the plate than the pasta. The sauce was delicately made, the sea urchin heated in a various degrees. They also served breads, 3 different kinds. The pasta itself was light on the portion, but with the bread eaten w/the leftover sauce, it was like heaven.I was so full, so I didn't want to eat anything more, not even a cake.So I ordered OJ (1200jpy plus 10%), which was ok, but a way bit pricy for the juice. Actually, MinuteMaid OJ is better than theirs. So, I'd love to return there and eat sea-urchin linguine again, but without OJ. I'd like to try their set menus, but the food comes as very big portions so the ladies at the table beside mine were declining desserts, saying they had too much. I wish they'd have set menus with less food and cheaper prices (say, around 2500jpy, w/coffee or tea, and petite dessert).

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I've been to this property several times and it has always been a terrific experience. The staff are very friendly and accomodating. The rooms are spacious and the bed is extremely comfortable. The gym is small but just what you need for a quick work out in the morning. Room service was very prompt and the food was good (very expensive, but that's Japan). The hotel shop doesn't have much of a selection, but they will gift wrap and deliver your purchase to your room. The location is good - depending upon what you want to do. You can walk to the Ginza (shopping) district and to the central train station. I look forward to my return!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: the location of the hotel near Tokyo station is perfect to visit tokyo and travel around
user_name:
muller j
bourg la reine france

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The concierge staff at the Four Seasons went out of thier way to find a particular type of stockings that my wife was looking for. After calling different retailers they were able to purchase the exact one she was looking for. Saved us a lot of time that we used to see more of Tokyo. Excellent location close to Tokyo station and Ginza shopping. Our favorite hotel in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The view was nothing special but everything else was top notch. The staff was incredibly helpful with dinner arrangements and made every effort to make our stay enjoyable.
user_name:
jim m
New York City, New York

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: My wife and I stayed for 5 days in October and it was excellent. We asked the conceirge for assistance several times and were pleasantly surprised on each occasion. I was particularly impressed by the effort that they went to in locating some noodles we were trying to bring back for our Japanese friend.The turndown service left a cake on my birthday complete with piped "Happy Birthday" chocolate decoration.Escorting us to our train on departure - right through the barriers and onto the correct train (which involved the conceirge buying herself a ticket!) was a nice touch.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I recently stayed at the Four Seasons Tokyo at Marunouchi and would certainly recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a great 5-star+ hotel in Tokyo. The location is fantastic for business travellers as its in the heart of the Marunouchi business district. We stayed for a family trip. Tokyo Station is just a 5 minute walk away where you can connect to JR and Tokyo Metro lines which allows travellers to easily access any part of Tokyo. The service is impeccable as expected from Four Seasons. Their concierges were our lifeline for booking restaurants, sights, tours, etc. They spoke perfect english. Rooms were a little smallish compared stays I've had with Four Seasons in Hong Kong but certainly not tiny by any standards. I love the wood and carpet in the rooms. A little dated but very nice and comfortable. Love the in room bodum and coffee that's complimentary. All in all a great hotel and stay, obviously expensive but what else would you expect from Four Seasons?

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Stayed 3 nights in a Superior Room.I pretty much like everything about Four Seasons at Marunouchi. Located next to Tokyo Station, in the middle of the business district and a 5 minutes walk from the main street in Ginza and the Imperial Palace.The staff is fantastic, the rooms are flawless - especially the beds and bathrooms are excellent.After the 11 hour flight, the 1 hour train trip (and the 20 minutes trying to get out of Tokyo Station :-) ), the coffee, delicious croissants, fruits and freshly squeezed orange juice waiting for me at the room, was highly appreciated.With less than 60 rooms, a good gym and ideal location, FS is the perfect base for a business trip and I will be staying here the next time as well.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Huge room, excellent bed, massive TV, wonderful spa, well maintained gym, fabulous cocktails, outstanding food, incredible bathroom, peace and quiet in a noisy part of town, small enough to be personal.Yes it's expensive (we were on a significant event anniversary splurge) but it's right in the middle of Tokyo, a stone's throw from the main railway station, they treat you very well indeed and make you feel like a proper guest, not a customer. Those needing a burst of exercise have fantastic gym and spa area to do that in, but I'd recommend the 8K run round the Imperial Palace.The food (with a welcome 25% off for residents) is great. The wagyu burger is a must try. As are the Vesper martinis. Yum yum yum.Would go back in a heartbeat.Only one quibble: the room rate is expensive. Please then explain to me why I should pay extra for internet access when every (and I mean every) other hotel we stayed in from 2 star to 5 star over a 2 week period in Japan had free internet? It's petty and mean guys: sort it out (especially when you're asking for nearly 20 pounds a day). You're in Japan, not Europe!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: If you read my other reviews you'll know I'm a demanding customer. We live in difficult times, and I will no longer hand my money over to hotels that give an inferior service. Japanese hotels are not cheap, however on the whole they can be the best. And I can say that my stay at the Four Seasons at Marunouchi was a very happy, smooth, classy experience.I'm writing this review from the perspective of someone who was in Japan on business - and this hotel worked for me on many levels. I like the fact it's small. I like the fact it's discreet. I rarely saw anyone unless I went up to the bar and lounge area. And I had a lovely big room that I was very happy to work in, watch TV in, and which endless Shinkasen silently race past my window .... and I was thrilled with my bed - a good hard bed. Oh, and the bathroom ... I could have taken a football team into my wet room for a shower. Excellent!At a few hours notice the hotel found me an excellent translator for an incredibly important business meeting, and not at an over-inflated price.I could also happily work on my laptop upstairs in the bar/lounge and feel so at ease, and hours would just slip away. No one pestered me, or bothered me. As is typical in Japan, the right level of attention was given.The Japanese staff were lovely - as were the other nationalities who worked in the hotel. There's an excellent African American gentleman who works in the bar area - he was slick, personable, and really took care of people.For my needs the location was very good. I found it easier to walk to Ginza subway station than try and tackle the huge Tokyo station which is currently under renovation. But I always have plenty to do in the Ginza anyway - and if you want to shop, then you NEED the Ginza. Everything from Chanel, LV, Prada - even Barney's New York are here.If I'm making the Ginza sound like an expensive area, it is. However, there's lots of little places to eat which are not ridiculously priced, especially around/underneath the Shinkasen train tracks, everything from noodles to sushi to the fabulous Freshness Burgers. Or eat at the hotel - the food was 1st class.If you want a buzzier evening and the Four Seasons is a little too sedate, then The Peninsula is about a 12 minute walk away ... yes, you should go there for a drink and enjoy the fabulous views from the bar. And I have also stayed there. But I would never stay at The Peninsula again, whereas I'll definitely be staying at The Four Seasons again. I'm already counting the days........

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We visited FS Marunouchi in April 2011, just a month after the 3.11 disaster in Japan.Pros-Rooms were simple - yet very modern, tasteful, and sophisticated. Spa facilities were really tiny, just accommodating handful people at the same time. But to our surprise, their skills were truly fantastic. Be sure to make a spa reservation in advance, and don't miss it. Cons-As this hotel is really small, you'll have very limited options everywhere in terms of facilities.In addition, the service was not up to our Four Seasons standard. Needs more staff overall (probably they were on "emergency shift" due to disaster, as the hotel had fewer guests). Spa reception was not manned and difficult to find staff. Bar was not that fantastic, a bit on the "cheap" side somehow. If you are to stay in Tokyo on business only and the location is a crucial matter to you, FS Marunouchi is not a bad choice at all. Very good access to JR Tokyo Station. But if not, I'd simply recommend you to consider Mandarin Oriental or Peninsula instead.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I felt I was treated like a movie star, service like I've never seen before, food fantastic,staff helpful and knowledgeble

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We were booked into this hotel as part of a private tour arranged by Japan Roads, which was fantastic. The ease of getting to the hotel from the Tokyo JR station, the friendly and helpful staff, the wonderful amenities, and the great food = a wonderful experience. We were a 5-10 minute walk from the Ginza, a 5-10 minute walk from the Imperial Palace gardens, and really, located centrally for the subway as well. I would stay here again in a minute!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Just spent 5 nights here, and cannot recommend this hotel highly enough.The hotel is very conveniently located only a few minutes from Tokyo Station (JR) and Marunouchi Station (Subway). Very easy to walk to many tourist sites including Ginza, the Imperial Palace and Tsukiji Fish Markets. I visited Park Hyatt, it's beautiful but location is not as good.Booked a standard room but was still wowed. The room had plenty of space for my friend and I, the king bed was heavenly and even the extra bed was comfortable (a single bed rather than flimsy metal with thin mattress). Bathroom was amazing ... Very modern with jet shower, deep soaking tub and large vanity. Amenities are L'Occitane and there was a range of accessories (combs, shaving kits, sewing kit etc.), pyjamas were also included. Found some other hotels to be quite loud, this was on a busy street but we didn't hear noise from traffic or any other guest. Food at Ekki Bar/Grill was superb and generously portioned. My favourite was the wagyu and foie gras burger. The Bar has a smoking and non-smoking area which is convenient. They have happy hour and offer 2 hour packages including cocktails. I have never seen this in a 5* hotel and was pleasantly surprised.The service is what really set this hotel apart, they are genuinely warm and there to help. I got greeted by name everywhere I went, and even from staff I hadn't met. They all seemed to know my itinerary (some better than me!) and were very helpful including organising a visit to Sumo beya to watch them train. Overall: Very, very happy and can't wait to return!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We stayed at the Four Seasons Marunouchi for six nights in an executive suite. We got a great deal from the website with every third night free. Prior to our stay we contacted the concierge (Akhil) via e-mail. He was very helpful arranging several meals and babysitting. We arrived early on Sunday morning and were met by a staff member at the airport and bus stop who took our bags across to the hotel. This was indicative of service during our stay - personalised. The room was great. Very spacious with nice fittings. The Nespresso machine was a good touch. The view was out over the tracks at Tokyo Station. Not a great deal of noise and quite interesting to watch the comings and goings, not to mention convenient for getting around Tokyo.The location of the hotel was ideal. Around a 5 minute walk to Ginza and 10 minutes to the Imperial Palace gardens. Quite a few restaurants in the surrounding area. The hotel restaurant served good quality food but quite expensive. There was a mix of Western and Japanese options. We stayed with our 9 month old son and they made him feel most welcome. They provided a stroller for us to use during our stay and a suite of amenities for him. They even went out and purchased nappies for us. The babysitting agency they used were great - very professional with excellent English.Overall, this is a wonderful small hotel but not cheap. It does not have all of the amenities of a big hotel but makes up for this with very personalised service. When we come back to Tokyo we'll stay here again.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Just one anecdote: My second day in the hotel, when I arrived back from business, the receptionist at the lobby recognized me using my name. The attention to detail and respect for customers was all through exceptional.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: My wife and i stayed at the FS marunouchi during our trip to Japan. The hotel is perfectly located in the center of Tokyo steps away from the Ginza Area , and right beside Tokyo Main Train station .The rooms are very spacious and are equiped with all the luxury amenities you would expect from a 5 star hotel. The furniture in the room is very crisp and relaxing yet luxurious. The staff would go out of thier way just to help you with anything. I have been to various FS hotels , but i have never seen hospitality like in Tokyo. The room at teh hotels all day dining restuarnat is to die for . You will especially appreciate it if you havnt developed the aquired taste for japanses food and you need western food that you are used to. On the downside the hotel is not located on a sky scraper as i assumed before going , and the hotel is very small ( that isnt particulary bad ) . My wife and i had expectations that the hotel woudl be similar to the mandarin oriental which is huge and is located on teh 26th 32nd floor of a sky scraper.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: EVERYTHING about this hotel was terrific.They arranged to meet me at the train platform, escorted me on foot underground to the hotel and from the moment I arrived, it was bliss.Large room for Tokyo. The bed was VERY comfortable. The room was quiet even though on a noisy street. The front desk staff were all so helpful. Breakfast was expensive (but delicious) and the view over Tokyo Station was nice. Although I speak no Japanese, the staff made sure I had no problems. Maid / housekeeping service was AWESOME. Always lots of bottled water, fresh ice & attention to the most minute detail. Very close to International Forum & assorted shopping as well as Palace. Gorgeous, safe neighborhood. This hotel & staff sets a high standard for other Four Season properties to match.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Stayed 3 nights at the Four Seasons on business. It was only about $100 more than a no name hotel that a colleagues stayed at but about 100 times nicer. The hotel is a work of art and examplifies Japanese workmanship and meticulous attention to detail. Super staff are very friendly and speak excellent English. Definitely will stay there again.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: four season hotels are great and this one is a very nice hotel, very friendly staff, a good service , clean large rooms, good food,but! there are two sides to this hotel! one that looks out on the street and one that backs onto a very busy railway station ! so it could be very noisy with the clunck of trains every few seconds going past your triple glazed windows ! its location is smack in the business district , so not that close to shops etc if thats what you want? it only has three floors I think 5,6,7, so your not that high up away from the streets or station. A nice hotel, but my advise ask for a room away from the Railway line and station, if you do stay.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The reception is NOT on the ground floor! It is not your typical hotel either. Smack dab in the lower floors of this building in the business district is the Four Seasons Hotel. The room is BIG. The decor is very zen like. They even provided me with a humidifier to ease the dry air. You don't see many other people on the way up to the room. It is located in Marunouchi and unless you have much to do here, you may have to walk a little bit more to get to the shopping area in Ginza. The Tokyo Station is located nearby though.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Stayed at the Four Seasons for four nights on a recent business trip to Tokyo. Firstly, the staff are brilliant, the concierge organized a trip and climb to Mt Fuji even before I had left home, most of the reception staff new me by name even when I arrived. The rooms are spacious and elegant without being over the top. Fabulous shower and separate bath. The restaurant though nice, was a little limited (especially for breakfast) and a little on the pricey side for what was available. The hotel location is great, close to Tokyo station and the Ginza which made it easy to get around. The spa was excellent as the staff had arranged for me to use on my return from Fuji on the way to Narita Airport. Great Place!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Stayed for three nights on holiday en route to New Zealand. Easy to find straight out of Tokyo station, turn right, 2nd buiding. Staff were very well drilled and efficient. Rooms were very spacious which is a bonus in Tokyo with a seating area and dressing area as well as the bed area. Bathroom well equipped with large bath and separate shower. Well located for Ginza and Tokyo station. Little restaurants below were fun, specially the sushi bar. We enjoyed Tokyo and the Four Seasons greatly and would recomment. The downside is the cost; we were on a 3 nights for the price of 2 package I guess because of the time of year, otherwise it would have been very expensive, as was the bar and food (£8 for a can of lemonade)

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The hotel was very convenient to the bus terminal which we used to come and go from the airport. The staff helped us with our luggage by coming to the terminal and walking us to the hotel. They assisted us with travel to Kyoto and were always ready to show us on a map where we needed to go. The baby was given every convenience ... crib, diapers, and a welcome gift. The room was beautiful and room service perfect. The staff was all you would want in a top end hotel.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I have to say I was a little bit disappointed with this hotel. The rooms are well appointed and the location is great - right near Tokyo Station and Ginza. I think it's a great option for business travellers - this is clearly their target market - but I don't think it's as well suited to those travelling for leisure. My husband and I were really overwhelmed by how generic it was - and whilst that might be what some travellers are after, I like my hotels to have a bit of soul.Granted we arrived late in the evening so probably didn't get the A team on staff but they really added little value. They had no recommendations on hand for somewhere to dine locally (we found a great spot in the Marunouchi Bldg nearby) and were generally a bit underwhelming. Staff on check out in the morning were very pleasant however.We only stayed one night so I do feel like we didn't get to experience everything they had to offer. I hope I'm not being overly harsh in my review as a result. The location is fabulous and I would stay here again if in Tokyo for work but not for pleasure.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Wonderful luxury hotel. They will do everything within their power short of murder to make sure your needs are met! Right next to Tokyo station and within an easy walk of the Ginza, you're in the center of the action. The only thing to consider is the view. Others in this class are high in the sky, while the four seasons only has views of the train station. They're very nice and you get to watch the bullet trains coming and going, but you are not 50 stories up.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Indulged myself on a shopping trip to Tokyo and stayed 3 nights at the Four Seasons Marunouchi. I totally enjoyed the service and attention provided by all the staff - really made my trip a memorable one. From the moment I stepped off the train at the Tokyo station, I was greeted by the staff and escorted to the hotel for check-in - even though I arrived just before 7am. I managed to nap for a few hours before heading out to start my shopping spree in Ginza!The location of the hotel is great - just minutes to Tokyo station and Ginza.Four Seasons has lived up to my expection and is now my favourite hotel brand.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: So we arrive in Tokyo, the four of us including my 5 month old daughter. We use their meet and greet service at the airport. The person speaks flawless engrish, buys the narita express tix, puts us on the train and informs the hotel which carriage we are in. In Tokyo a four seasons porter takes our luggage and helps us emerge from the labyrinthine station. Coffee and drinks at the reception till we are shown to our room. The room is huge with the bathroom as big as the room at the imperial hotel where we stayed the last time. For the baby they provided a beautiful cot, a baby bath and even diapers. On a sidenote, buying diapers in Tokyo around the ginza district is a massive hassle. Carry sufficient quantities. The lobby has spectacular views and has a one computer access to the Internet. U need to get a thumb drive from the desk. All rooms have wireless connections but they are a tad expensive. The staff are wonderful. Right from the people manning the door downstairs, to the concierge with flawless recommendations, to room service. The attention to detail is stunning. Of all the four seasons I have stayed in this easily has the best service. Keep in mind that I am benchmarking against hotels in the same chain which is a high bar to start off with. Here is an example. Kids mean Tokyo Disney, approached with dread by parents all over. I am referring to Disney in general and not singling out Tokyo Disney. Getting there entails taking the metro and there is a station with a direct train about a 10 mins walk. But we have a stroller and Tokyo seems to have been designed with the firm intention of discouraging kids and the use of strollers. So a staff member escorts us all the way to the train. She knows every cunningly hidden ramp and elevator. She even buys a metro ticket so that she can take us right into the train. I marvel at this and swear never to choose any other hotel in Tokyo. Neither should you!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The whole experience here is amazing. From being met at the station platform, to the personalised service and the overall attention to detail, I think this place is hard to beat. After staying at two underwhelming Four Seasons (Vancouver and Geneva), this place really does live up to the brand.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Service culture in Japan is world-renowned for excellence and the Four Seasons at Marunouchi exemplifies it so well. From the arrival greeting to the ease at check out and personal escort to Tokyo Station, Four Seasons at Maruouchi made my stay one I will fondly remember. This small hotel - just 57 rooms - sets the standard for exceptional, personalised service and one that other hotels can look to emulating.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I cannot recommend the Four Seasons Marunouchi highly enough. It is literally at the central train station, Tokyo Station, so convenient for all travel. The staff will even meet you on the platform and drop you off, which is fabulous if you are jet-lagged or just plain overwhelmed by the confusion of Tokyo Station. The rooms were beyond fabulous -- huge, luxurious, with amazing views. We had booked a standard room and they upgraded us to unbelievable suites both times we stayed there. The staff was extremely welcoming to children and went out of their way to add special touches, like bringing a birthday cake for my son with both Japanese and English on it. If you need the perfect place to start or end a trip to Japan, book a room here.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: My boyfriend and I stayed here last November and still rave about it to friends. Granted, it's small and not especially grand for a Four Seasons, but the staff members are wonderful, particularly an incredibly charming and helpful young man named Minabu (sp?), who is truly a gem and a consummate professional. I don't love Marunouchi, but I would stay here again in a heartbeat, especially if Minabu is still working there. Plus the Japanese breakfast is stunningly good!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Being in the business district might not appeal to tourist but being next to Tokyo station and having luxurious and comfortable rooms with the usual Four Seasons service does have its perks. Stayed in this hotel on the tail end of a week long vacation to Tokyo and it was a wonderful way to end the holiday. Rooms were large and comfortable. Service was great – from the bell desk to the front desk to housekeeping. Excellent Concierge – good recommendations and was able to get us a last minute reservation at a popular sushi place.As with lot of subways in Tokyo, the stations can be a maze. What I really like was the bell desk walking us to the train platform to catch the Narita Express to the airport. I couldn’t image finding our way through the crowd and different levels to get to the platform.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: EXCEPTIONAL service. The entire staff was dedicated to our satisfaction.High quality accommodation. Fine decoration. Central location in the business and shopping areasFS Marunouchi is really one of the top Internaltional luxury hotels.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We thoroughly enjoyed our two nights at the Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi. It was at the tail end of our 16 day stay in Japan, after traveling the country from Takayama, Koyasan,Osaka, Hiroshima, Miyajima and Kyoto. We stayed those nights at ryokans and a shukubo (Buddhist temple lodging), so we welcomed the opportunity to sleep in Western-style beds. We were traveling with my parents (in their 70s) and my child (6 years old) and they gave us adjoining rooms on the third floor. They even set up a twin size bed in the room for my daughter. We were greeted warmly when we arrived (though we got there before check-in) and they presented my daughter with a toy. They also brought up a personalized cookie for my daughter once we were settled in our rooms. The rooms were decorated very tastefully in neutral colors. The room was extremely quiet (considering the hotel is close to Tokyo Station) and we didn't hear any street noise. If you didn't look out your window, you might not realize you were in Japan. We've stayed at Four Seasons in Costa Rica and Bahamas (now closed), and though I might prefer them more, the Four Seasons in Marunouchi is a luxurious and peaceful haven to relax and recharge. The concierge was extremely helpful with his directions and recommendations (Ginza Ichitei). The front desk printed out maps and directions so we could go to the Ghibli Museum and find our train to the airport. This was the perfect cap to our Japan vacation.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Caveat: We weren't the average guests -- harried mom traveling with 3 young kids for leisure but with business to attend to as well. Though some Japanese friends initially wondered what we were thinking booking this hotel in the business district, it proved an excellent base for our family to explore Tokyo - next to Tokyo Station, near Ginza and all sorts of other shopping options. The platform greeting at Tokyo Station was really super, though I'd agree with others who felt awkward watching white-uniformed men and women sweating and toiling for us as we addled along with nary a care in that labyrinth!Our corner room - premium, double-queened beds that are so, so hard to find in Asia! - was fantastic. Extremely simple decor and lovely bathroom were appropriately Japanese cool. Two walls of glass to view the twinkling lights and bullet train wonderment and automatic shades alone kept my kids enraptured. It isn't true that you don't hear the trains - we did - but somehow it became more of a benign white noise. Service was impeccable, though the concierge had a tough time understanding that casual Italian or Tepanyaki with kids simply doesn't translate to "jacket required" types of places. The true weak link for us was the food. Excellent teen hamburger but inedible "spaghetti" and since we had wonderful spaghetti elsewhere it isn't that the dish doesn't translate. We just ate (mostly Japanese food) elsewhere. Amusing/charming that they supplied toddler tumblers and tiny bath robes for kids even after asking us to confirm their ages (9 and 13) twice! Gym was small and okay, not great, but locker room had a nice onsen. Loved it.I so love that the FS meaningfully welcomes families who enjoy traveling -- it's why we selected it in Tokyo even when other locations seemed more obviously appropriate for us and though we typically try to stay at more local-style hotels. The staff made sure our son had a separate rollaway and somehow made it luxurious, they never failed to greet us with smiles, and really took care of us for the duration, whether it was waking at 3 for Tsukiji or responding to obscure art-related questions. Service makes a difference!
user_name:
kartwoman
Washington DC, District of Columbia

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: After reading all of the glowing reviews on this site we booked this hotel for our family for our first trip to Tokyo (kids ages 9 and 11). Since we had never been to Japan before we did a lot of research to attempt to find the perfect hotel for a family stay - basically it was between this hotel and the peninsula, but we chose four seasons marunouchi because of the extra service that we thought would be available for the children. Unfortunately in practice virtually none of these services were actually delivered. Initially we booked premier rooms but when we found that these rooms did not face the train station we switched to the smaller superior rooms - that may be why we didn't have the extra services, so check before you book. We were expecting (based on prior reviews on this site, and information available elsewhere) welcome gifts for the children, child sized bathrobes and toiletries, and a special age appropriate childrens treat, such as milk and cookies, delivered on the night of arrival. Unfortunately when we arrived there were no welcome gifts for the children (which was sad since I had mentioned this to the kids prior, and yes they were very disappointed - bad daddy), the child sized bathrobes we finally found 1 in each room (in the closet behind the door) - same with the too small kid slippers, and absolutley no childrens toiletries (we had not brought any based on this information so will have to purchase in the morning). Of course given this track record our expectations were definitely lowered so that when we returned to the hotel the night of our arrival and found no cookies in sight we were not necessarily surprised, but the childrens disappointment at these ommisions cannot be overlooked. The reason we picked this hotel over the Peninsula is that this hotel was definitely advertised as being family friendly by offering these ameneties - where the Peninsula charged extra for these types of services - so if you are considering these two hotels for a family stay I would seriously consider the Peninsula over this location - you get what you pay for.Further, on the lack of attention to detail side - several weeks before we arrived I called ahead to have a playstation installed in the childrens room (the one that was supposed to contain the small robes, toiletries and cookies). Of course when we arrived there was no playstation in either room, so I went down to the concierge to request one. The concierge confirmed that there was a playstation available and that it would be delivered immediately. 15 minutes later my son came over to tell me that they were installing the WII. Not a playstation, but a wii, so I went next door to once again (for a 3rd time) request a playstation but my son intervened (I think he was happy to get anything) so we settled for the wii. This is a very nice hotel and the staff is very kind and helpful but when expecations meet reality it is shown to be less than favorable on balance. If you are looking for that perfect family experience at a 5 star you might consider somewhere that these services can be purchased - or at least one that has a swimming pool. There are no extra services available for children here, and honestly why bother to gather age and gender information for the kids if that information won't be put to any use?. Also don't expect to be shown the ameneties of the room upon arrival - checkin was very quick - bascially here's your luggage, sign here please, goodbye. We spent the next 20 minutes figuring out how to work the blinds, the lights, the toilets (yes, the toilets took a bit - kind of high tech for an American), the TV, etc... Its a very luxurious and high tech room, and figuring out all of the controls took a bit of investigation.I would also qualify this as a potential difference between the premier and superior rooms, but none of the premier rooms face the train station - so if you have your heart set on this hotel for a family stay - call ahead!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We stayed for 4 nights at the Four Season's Marunouchi. In spite of some of the downside reviews from some tripadvisor respondents, I went ahead to book the hotel through tablet.com. The hotel is a 2 minute walking distance to the Tokyo Station and is a 5-7 minute walk to the Ginza shopping area. What makes this a fabulous place is that is situated in an area that bring peace and serenity and splendor to Tokyo. The room was big! The bathroom was huge! And everything was more than what I imagined the place to be! It was a jewel to behold as I had stayed in other business hotels in Japan and this one tops the list by a mile! Imagine that the hotel is just on the street, but the windows are sound proof. You can't hear anything on the street! There are two concierge - at the 7th floor and the ground floor lobby. What is excellent is the platform meet and greet service and for an extra $60 you can even have someone greet you right at the doorstep of the airport exit! The greatest thing here is that I did not need a translator. The staff speak perfect English and when you asked them for directions, you won't get lost in translation in this city! Next time I'm in Tokyo, I definitely will stay here again. As for those that complain about the price, well, I don't think you should book yourselves in a place that you can't afford. Luxury does not come cheap!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: My husband and I have just returned from an 8 day stay in Tokyo. Our first trip to Japan. As per other comments on Trip Advisor, we are unable to fault this hotel. We are seasoned travellers enjoying luxury accommodation around the world and this branch of the Four Seasons will meet your expectations.Location is superb above Tokyo station if you are keen to pack as much into your stay like ourselves by shooting off all over the country with the incredible efficiency of the Japanese rail network.As per other comments, do make use of the concierge "meet and greet" service on your first arrival into Tokyo station from the airport - it just takes that extra hassle off you when you first arrive before you have managed to familiarise yourself with the station if you are a first-timer!Every member of staff speak excellent English and can't do enough to make your stay perfect.We decided to keep eating at the hotel to a minimum to help with our budget - yes, the food is expensive but you are staying at a Four Seasons in one of the most expensive cities in the world so it comes with the territory! We had a couple of breakfasts in the hotel which, whilst expensive, the food was certainly of the highest quality and could not be faulted.Rooms were perfect, spacious and comfortable with delightful bathrooms.Go ahead and book, you won't regret it!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: we started our trip to japan with three days here and are we glad we did! it is a beautiful hotel with a calm, quiet, understated elegance that we loved - especially after long days out and about in the city. service was exceptional - starting with the personal greeting at tokyo station. i would recommend this hotel to first time visitors to tokyo for this service (no extra fee) alone! the station is huge and very confusing so having english speaking staff from the hotel waiting to meet you as soon as you get off the train from the airport can be a godsend - it certainly was for us! all you have to do is call them before leaving narita to let them know when you'll be arriving and they will be waiting to collect you and your luggage as soon as you step off the train - not sure how well we would have managed on our own without this help. same thing on departure - they will bring you exactly where you need to be inside the station so there is no stress at all. also loved being able to explore the area around the imperial palace - which is right by the hotel - on the bicycles they provided (again with no extra charge). location is absolutely perfect - easy access to the train station and subway lines, and short walk (beautiful at night) to lots of wonderful shops and restaurants in ginza (we particularly enjoyed faro - a wonderful michelin star restaurant recommended by the concierge). we didn't end up eating at the hotel so i can't comment on the food, but i can tell you the beds were the best we have slept in any where. we loved this place and would definitely recommend it. we also stayed at the peninsula at the end of our trip and loved that too - but starting out here was perfect!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: A few paces from Tokyo station, the location of this hotel is as close to perfect as it's possible to be. Finding the entrance is a minor challenge, and a friend visiting me said that finding the parking lot was a more epic challenge.Check in and check out were silky-smooth. The staff seem to work out who you are without any prior information (can they ALL be former CIA?). The room was a good size, with a nice bathroom (separate shower and toilet cubicles, and a good deep long bath). The decor is standard understated modern chic (a contrast with the chintzy faux-European style of the Four Seasons Chinzan-so on the other side of town). The room had all you'd expect (kettle etc, ipod and CD player, LAN and wireless connections...). All I could be pissy about was the lack of bath salts for soaking in the big bath! The bed was supremely comfortable.I ate out in the evening, but ordered a simple a la carte breakfast, which was delivered uncannily as I liked it, but was charged less than the menu might have allowed. I entertained some business associates on a Sunday afternoon, and tea for three was an eye-popping US$50-ish, but I guess that should compare with the cost of a quiet meeting room rather than a tea bag or two. A Fedex snafu also meant a last minute flurry of colour printing which the concierge handled with no stress - and no extra charge on my bill! The only lapse was when I wanted to send a bag ahead, by express courier (takkyubin) to the airport, and the collected staff wisdom couldn't work out how far in advance they should send it. But the (junior) staff member, took very un-Asian responsibility for either making it happen or contacting me to work out options.
