I was impressed more than I was inconvenienced.The rooms here are expensive, but you really get the most extraordinarily personal service, in an uber-central location, from where you can watch shinkansen from your bed (I've developed a new brand of eroticism - engineering porn - those bullet trains are just soooooo slinky). By the way, all the staff speak impressive English. I didn't need my stumbling Japanese once.It's probably one of the 2-3 most expensive hotels in Tokyo, but if your budget allows, you won't be disappointed.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The Four Seasons seem to do better than anyone else where ever you go. We arrived here with our two kids aged 17 and 7 after spending 3 days in the Shinjuku area of Tokyo which seemed overwhelmingly busy whereever we ventured. The Four Seasons Marunouchi is located adjacent to Tokyo station in the heart of the central district so it is very convenient for sightseeing via subway to almost any area of Tokyo and is within walking district of the Imperial Palace. The hotel is small by comparison to most other hotels in the area but is big on service. From the "Welcome Cookie" plate our 7 year old received to the robes and kimono's sized just right for our entire family the hotel does it well. We dined at the hotels' restaurant "Ekk'i" and whilst it was on the pricey side as most of Tokyo\s restaurants are it was excellent food and service and we took advantage of the half price wine offer which made the dinner bill a bit more reasonable. If you are a train enthusiast you will love observing the Bullet train entering and leaving the station right from the view from your window..but you don't hear them as the hotel seemed incredibly soundproofed. If you are looking for some more reasonable places to grab a bit, try the Cafe Paul, just around the corner from the hotel in the plaza where delicious fresh light foods and bakery made the most mouth watering treats and coffees. The only disadvantage is they don't open til 11am so the morning coffee is a long wait. That is also consistent of all the shops and amenities in the surround area which was disappointing when as Westerners you wake up early for the day. Make sure to visit the Fish Market also near by for eye popping discoveries and a visit to a Tea Ceremony is a must also in Tokyo. One final thought is be prepared to plan ahead for dining and make reservations as we found that if we showed up without we were almost always in for a long wait.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We stayed here during our first trip to Tokyo. It is as good as depicted in previous reviews. We were met by a hotel rep once we got off the Narita Express at Tokyo Station and the hotel was a quick 5min stroll. They did not have a room available for an early check in but they did store our bags for us while we went for a stroll around the Imperial Palace and had lunch. The room we had (superior with King bed) was lovely, and the bathroom was stocked with L'Occitane products. The hotel provides free WI-FI which I had problems accessing on my iphone in the room, but it works perfectly in the lobby. They did try to get it to work but it appears that WI-FI access via the iphone can be problematic in Japan.All our requests for information was attended to competently by staff, whom all spoke perfect English. They checked Shinkansen times (although I already knew which ones were suitable for our travel plans) and offered to purchase tickets for us (Additional Service charge and tax applicable). TIP: go on an adventure and get your own tickets from the Shinkansen office at Tokyo Station, it is not difficult and the hotel can precheck the times for you. All restaurant recommendations were fantastic.The location of the hotel itself it great. It is next to the major train station, and close to Ginza. Roppongi is a bit further away. There are great restaurants close by.At the end of our stay, they assisted with our baggage and walked us to our Shinkansen. The little lady who sent us off even wanted to help with our huge luggage, but my husband decided it would be ungentlemanly of him to carry nothing.I will definitely stay here again. The service was excellent, even compared to other hotels in the Four Seasons chain.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Well situated for a first time traveler to Tokyo conveniently located at Tokyo Station. We paid $60 for airport transfer to the Narita Express (train from the Narita Airport to Tokyo Station). The airport agent met us after customs and immigrations, took us to the nearest ATM, train ticketing machine, rushed us to the train and contacted The Four Seasons with our train car number and arrival information. "Meet and greet service" was an outstanding complimentary service offered by this Four Seasons Hotel. The hotel agent then met us with a luggage cart outside our train car in the busy Tokyo station. He led us through the maze to the hotel where we were able to check-in inside our hotel room. We booked under the “buy 2 nights, get one free” for a total of approximately $1,000 for 3 nights stay in the smallest room. The sleek room was comfortable with modern appointments including, smart room technology, a bathroom TV, fancy Japanese style toilet, luxury vanity items and a deep tub. The triple-paned windows provided a very quiet stay despite the adjacent Shinkansen Train Station next door. We do not speak Japanese and were glad to find that the staff all spoke excellent English. They went out of their way to ensure our comfort, providing area information and facilitating tour purchase (hotel fee was 10% of ticket price). We enjoyed the “Dynamic Tokyo Tour” and also spent a rainy day in Kyoto. A group of students provide free site seeing tours to show off their historic city while practicing English. The Four Seasons staff always greeted us by name and provided umbrella use (it poured during our time there) and complimentary water. They prepared a delicious cake for my birthday! The business center allowed free internet access. Modern spa facilities were available. The hotel thought of everything, including loan of athletic wear should a guest require. Nothing in Tokyo was inexpensive and the hotel restaurant was no exception. A breakfast of hot chocolate and waffles would cost around $25; dinner ran about $50 per entree. Thankfully, we discovered a Starbucks two blocks away. We would unconditionally recommend this hotel because of the courteous staff, beautiful décor, nice spa, helpful services, and great location.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I was in Tokyo on business and stayed 6 nights at this hotel. Location is very good, a short distance from Tokyo station. I chose to use the greeting service as this was my first time in Tokyo. As it turned out, finding ones way to the Narita Express was rather easy, ticket boot included. However, I would recommend this service if you for instance need to get things done at the airport before going to Tokyo (such as picking up rental phone etc), or if you don't feel like doing the job of finding out arrival time at Tokyo Station and then call the hotel and setup a pickup time. Because I would strongly recommend that you use the hotel's pickup service at Tokyo Station (which comes at no cost). Tokyo Station is large, often crowded, and it's actually quite easy to get lost there.I stayed in a Superior Room, which is the simplest room type at the hotel. The room was quite nice and facing the main street, the interior almost impeccable. A few small downside points regarding the room:- lighting felt a bit inadeqaute when dark outside (which is rather common at hotels nowadays, often due to the use of low energy lamps), you couldn't get it really bright if you wanted to- although 42" TV, the TV set felt slightly outdated, and the channels offered were rather poor. One of the channels had good enough films on during Friday to Saturday at least- there was a dock for my iPhone, however this was connected to the TV speakers, which made for a rather poor sound experience. So a nice thought, but not very well implemented. The cost of a pair of decent speakers would have been a worthwhile investment.Otherwise, the room was very nice, the street view too, a good working desk, an internet connection for 2k jpy per 24 hrs that worked adequately (only used it by wifi), nice reading chair, quite nice bed, very nice bathroom and toiletries, etc.I used the gym once, quite nice, adequately equipped and with a very nice view. You get a locker key at the desk at floor 7, and you've got everything you need, so you only need to bring your workout clothes there. I didn't have the time to use the onsen (a real onsen btw, with spring water, onsen water is actually provided to hotels in Tokyo).However, what really sets this hotel apart is the service. Only one hickup when it comes to the staff - they were not 100% up-to-date with which rate should apply to my booking. This didn't present much of a problem though, and as a traveler one always need to look after this aspect as a general part of managing the trip, so no big deal. They immediately adjusted the rate, and that was it. On another note - I had one sleep-out night, which was no problem at all, I got to keep my room, as well as the rate (every third night on the house).Just a few words on the Ekki Restaurant before I go on with the staff in general. I have read a lot of reviews mentioning that the restaturant is very expensive. For one...if this is an issue, there are lots of other restaurants not far away. Also, the restuarant has combined menues (at least for those who stay at the hotel) which provide for 3 or 4 course dinners at a much lower rate. And what's more - the cuisine is quite good. I had one 4 course dinner, and was very satisfied, especially the grilled fish that actually made me chuckle between the bites, it was sooo good!! I was also very impressed with their timing and high degree of attentiveness. Everything arrived on precise time, and the waiter immediately noticed if something needed to be done. The meal and the service taken together made it all quite worth it for me.The hotel staff was very service minded, kind and thoughtful, and competent! They would always go beyond my expectations. When I asked the Concierge to book tickets on the bullet train (Shinkansen) for instance, they would come up with a better route than the one that I had found. They would also escort me to the train, at no cost, and ask if I needed somebody to meet me when returning. When I asked the Concierge to book a table at a restaurant with a short notice, the staff at ground floor printed out a map for me, plus made a note with a detailed yet easy to understand description of how to get there, including where to change trains and expected duration for each stretch of the trip (also finding a better way than the one I had initially thought of myself). This was ready when I arrived at ground floor on my way out. The day I left, one of the staff members escorted me to the Narita Express (taking care of my luggage as well), and we arrived rather early, some 25 minutes before the train was supposed to leave. Without hesitation the staff member offered me the opportunity to go shopping or whatever until departure time. As I didn't have any need to do any such thing, I said thanks, but no thanks. I was then asked whether I needed assistance to get the luggage onto the train - which I obviously didn't - i e the person was offering to stay around for another 20 minutes just to carry my bags on board. I kindly declined. But this is the kind of service they provide. This goes on and on. When it comes to these things, I am not easily impressed, but this staff did impress me over and over again. They were very good at spotting my needs, including to see if they could come up with something better than what I was actually asking for. I have never experienced anything close to this before.If it hasn't dawned on you yet - if you choose to stay at this hotel, do use the Concierge service, they will do the work for you, and faster and better than you ever could, while you do something more interesting or entertaining. I can't emphasise enough the value of this service.I give my very best recommendations for this hotel to anyone who values a high degree of service, and nice accomodation.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: First Time in Japan. We went to Japan to celebrate out anniversary. We arrived on the evening of my birthday. After 5 minutes we entered to our room, room service brought a beautiful cake, Cleanliness on the room and the entire hotel was perfect. Great Restaurant, great food and service.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We recently spent 5 nights at the Four Seasons located near the Ginza. The hotel itself is right on top of Tokyo train station, which is ideal for getting to and from the airport quickly and cheaply (by tokyo standards). The hotel offers a greeting service at Narita which we took advantage of. My girlfriend and I arrived on separate flights and terminals, we were both meet by separate hotel employees who expertly coordinated our meeting on the train. We were then met at Tokyo station by a young lady half my size who insisted on expertly carting our luggage through the crowds at Tokyo station....it was a very short walk to the hotel and we were quickly taken to our suite on the 7th floor, where we checked in our room. The suite consisted of 2 separate rooms, a living room, with work desk mini bar etc, a large bedroom and a separate bath with tub and walk in shower. All very nice, modern japanese style, The room has wi-fi, ipod players and flat screen television in every room. The bed was very comfortable, and dispite the room overlooking Tokyo station, fairly quiet, although you could hear the trains a bit, but not enough to disturb you. We used room service quite often for breakfast or a late night snack, pretty good selection of western and japanese styles, room service was prompt and friendly. The hotel has one restaurant, which I had breakfast in one morning, it was very good. but we didnt have dinner there. The gym is small but functional. The Concierge was excellent, helping us with dinner suggestions and arranging some touristy adventures outside Tokyo. We enjoyed our stay here,

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I love this place and would deffo recomend to any people thinking of staying here.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Location, location. Service was top notch. Worth the expense in every way. I booked it because of the reviews on TA and agree with all the other visitors. Easy access to the train station and all the accountriments for my business activities.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We treated ourselves to a 2 night stay here with our son. On arrival they had a personalized dish of treats for him,together with a welcome pack for babies,which was a nice touch, a boys crib (better than what he had at home!!!) and the usual hotel bits you'd get. The room was very modern as you would expect, massive window/wall overlooking the tokyo metro station (much to our sons joy) electric everything,dvd with large selection of music/films to use. Large bathroom,with everything you could wish for. Hot spa room, very nice but not very big. We also had in room treatments here, and facial in their spa. The food was quite good though not as good as we were expecting (t his is a little vague but I'm reviewing this quite some time after our trip!) if there was one thing we were slightly disappointed with it would be that, but otherwise we felt well looked after,and enjoyed the surroundings of this hotel.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: This hotel is a gem. The location is fabulous. Right in the heart of Tokyo, minutes walk from Ginza and the Imperial Palace. It is literally attached to Tokyo station, so you can get almost anywhere in the country very quickly. Kyoto, for example, would be only about 2 hours by bullet train. Nagoya about the same. Narita airport is only about 40 minutes. We took our daughter to Disney and it was only 15 minutes from the hotel (by train). So, this hotel really has our vote for best location.The hotel itself is very intimate. Everyone knows your name, and the staff cannot do enough to help. The rooms are very spacious (we had a corner premier room and it felt like an apartment). We were also amazed at how clean and quiet our room was. It is hard to imagine a hotel in the heart of downtown Tokyo where one could feel more private and more comfortable. The hotel even has onsen (hot spring) baths. So, every morning, I would jog around the palace and return for a nice soak---it was really the life.My only nitpick is that the food is really expensive (as is the norm in Tokyo hotels). A burger from room service would run like 40 dollars. Since we were not traveling on business, we did not partake of the hotel's food (although I am sure it is quite good). Nonetheless, because of the hotel's location, there are many incredible food options in the immediate area. There are literally hundreds of restaurants right outside the door, so we didn't think twice about not be able to eat in the hotel.This hotel carries my highest recommendation. However, the rates fluctuate tremendously. If not traveling on business, try booking online during an off peak time to get a better rate.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: This is an impressive hotel. Weeks before our arrival the hotel had already exceeded our expectations and made our trip to Japan so incredibly easy and the perfect short holiday. From booking our day-trip tickets to Kyoto on the Nozomi train, tables at restaurants and responding to our other enquiries, the Four Seasons certainly knows how to impress. The concierge staff were exceptional... no other hotel even comes close. On arrival at Tokyo station from Narita Airport a staff member met us at the platform and piled our luggage onto a trolley. The suitcase stack was taller than her but she insisted on pushing it through the huge station. We were so glad she had met us as we feared if she hadn't we would have been lost in the station for at least four days - it is gigantic and a bit of a maze - accept the hotel's offer to be collected.The hotel has a boutique feel with only 57 rooms. Our room was spacious with a lovely bathroom, wonderful black floor boards to give it a modern Japanese feel and modern decor. The toilets were of course amazing with lots of buttons... I want one in my home. The location is perfect - you are a short stroll from Ginza and the Imperial Palace. I went for a 6km jog around the palace each morning... a nice way to start the day. The gym is also very well equipped. This hotel certainly ticked all the right boxes and we would definitely stay here again. Thanks to all the staff, particularly the amazing concierge staff who made this trip so memorable.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We go to Tokyo every year, but it's the first time we stayed with Four Seasons Marunouchi. We usually stayed in Shibuya where we could shop till late hours. This time, we also visited Osaka, and we took the Nozumi (bullet train) to Tokyo. Since we're only staying in Tokyo for 3 nts., with the extended stay promotion, FS (with free roll-away bed) was only a slight premium to our regular hotel (our 3-bed-room has always been of premium price).I must say on arrival, I wasn't very impressed. (1) FS's platform greeting service was great. However, maybe we have not specified we had a lot of luggages (4 big & 2 small), Concierge did not come with a luggage cart, and we ended up having to carry our luggages to the Hotel, which was a few blocks away. (2) We arrived at 12:30 p.m., and our room was not ready. We had to leave our luggage there, and check-in in the evening after our visit to Harajuku. (3) No free internet, but the Hotel allows you to use their Business Centre for free.Check-in was smooth, and our room was great. We requested wii for our teenager son, and it was already inside the room with a lot of games and complimentary Japanese snacks. Needless to say, our son was very impressed. The Hotel also has X-Box and PS3. My son changed from wii to PS3 the following evening after he got bored with the wii games.The room, as well as the bathroom, was spacious and comfortable. Even the roll-away bed was the most comfortable ever.The Hotel is at a very convenient location. We usually took metro from the Kyobashi station, which was the closest to the Hotel, and the most convenient line to places like Ginza, Shibuya, and Asakusa. It is also quite close to Tsukiji Fish Market. We regreted not taking Concierge's advice to take a taxi there (about 1,000 yen?). We arrived at 7:20 a.m., but had to wait for 2 hr 40 min. Should we arrive earlier by taxi, maybe we did not have to wait for so long. However, the sushi was so fresh and delicious it's well worth the wait - the Ultimate Tsukiji experience!Since we have a lot of luggages, the Front Receptionist advised us to take the Airport Lumousine, which was closer to the Hotel, and stopped right in front of Departure Lvl., instead of Narita Express, which was on a different lvl. We were escorted to the Bus Terminal, and this time, we did not have to carry our luggages.Overall, we had an enjoyable stay. It's very difficult for us to choose between our regular hotel in Shibuya, which offers all the shopping convenience VS FS, which has the luxurious comfort and services, and proximity to the Tsukiji Fish Market.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Met a friend for a weekend in Tokyo. Both had been traveling for business. We indulged ourselves with a stay at the Four Seasons Marunouchi. Everything that has been said here is true. It is an exquisite small property but with 100% customer service. The concierge assisted with travel by bullet train to Kyoto and the Miho museum. This was a great day trip. Upon our return, we received great recommendations for meals. The hotel restaurant is also great. I enjoyed the visit and hope to return again soon.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I had never been to Tokyo before and since I had only three days I decided to take advantage of the extended stay promotion. It was worth it; the service from the time FS staff picks you up at Tokyo station to when they drop you off at the same place is perfect. You should make sure to take advantage of the excellent concierge service, they give great advice about restaurants and local area attractions. Also, make use of the bikes for exploring the area around the hotel, including the Imperial gardens.About the room, mine had a great view of Tokyo Forum and the trains. They are very well appointed and from what I heard from other people large by Tokyo standards. In summary, if you can stay here, do it.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I stayed at the FS Marunouchi with my 8-year-old son. We snuck away for a long weekend in Tokyo. I spent a little extra for a corner room, and asked for a view of the trains. My son was blown away, and hours learning about the bullet trains. He'd see one from the window, run to my computer, and within a minute would know where the train was going (nice geography lesson, BTW).The hotel staff are the best I've ever seen (equal or better than Oriental in Bangkok, St Regis in NYC, etc.). The professionalism is felt from the top, and was evidenced by the GM who was quite natural in bringing us our lunch in the lounge and never made mention of his role (obviously was helping because of a sudden rush to the main dinning room that took our servers attention for a few minutes). The pickup at the station is sooooo worth it! And the concierge is spectacular! They even booked us a room in a Ryokan in Nozawa Onsen at the last minute, booked all the trains, and even printed out a note for the taxi upon arrival in the mountains. Everything was perfect!Most importantly, this is a hotel that understand what you need. My son is a sushi fanatic and they recommended places that we would feel comfortable (in the fish market, and nearby the hotel). Even one of the sushi places that was "higher end" was obviously briefed by the hotel and, when we arrived, they took us to a small little space that was protected but we could still feel the action at the bar.True, the hotel costs a bomb, and it is worth every penny. I will definitely go back!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: My wife and I stayed at the Four Seasons Marunouchi for 3 nights in May 2009. Simply put, we had a first class experience, just as one would expect from the Four Seasons.As it was our first visit to Japan, we used the hotel "meet and greet" service. It was exactly as promised (recurring theme during our stay). A very pleasnat lady was waiting outside of arrivals for us, arranged our transportation into Tokyo (Narita Express) and walked us to the train car. When we arrived at Tokyo Station, a member of the Concierge staff was waiting for us on the train platform and walked us to the hotel. Watching her steer our 2 suitcases through the bustle of Tokyo Station during evening rush hour was truly impressive. We were glad we arranged this service, although signage is in both Japanese and English, we would never have found our way out of the Station !The hotel occupies part of the first 7 floors of an office building adjacent to the train station. Decor is not overtly Japanese, and most of the local feel is achieved via artwork. The room itself was quite comfortable, very spacious and all fixtures, amenities etc were of exceptional quality. Our room faced the street, but soundproffing was excellent. Due to allergies, we requested a non-feather room, and that is exactly what we had. Having made this reequest numerous times over the years, this property was one of the VERY few that actually fulfilled the request.One quick note about concierge service. We traded emails back and forth with the concierge before our visit, asking for advice and questions on various topics. As you would expect, theyhandled all requests with efficiency and courtesy. We had seen signs advertising the play "Wicked" in the Shio-dome area, and one morning I asked the Concierge if he could provide me with details (time, location, etc). Although he clearly was not familiar with the play, he (via the magic of Internet) determined that there was no performance that particular day. [Why anyone would spend 3 hours in Tokyo seeing a play they had seen before is another story....]. We then had breakfast in the hotel restaurant and during the meal, the Concierge came up, apologized for interrupting, and let me know he was wrong earlier and there was in fact a performace that day at 1 pm. Since we were planning on shopping in the Ginza, we did not go see the play, but we were impressed by his work ethic and desire to satisfy customers.My wife had a massage in the Spa and was very satisfied. The masseuse did not merely go through the motions, and was quite willing to work extra on those pesky problem muscles.TIP: the hotel itself is in a great location. Being a short walk away from Tokyo Station makes anywhere in Tokyo easily accessible by train/subway. Tokyo Station however is quite busy, and we found that the Kyobashi Station on the Ginza line was just as close to the hotel and was very lightly used. Unless it makes your destination difficult to get to, I would recommend using Kyobashi instead of Tokyo. If you want to use the Ginza line (Ginza, Shibuya, Ueno) this Station gives you a direct, no connection, route.The hotel restaurant was excellent, all food was prepared exactly as requested and made with the finest quality ingredients. Undoubtedly some of the reviews (which I have not read) will be critical of pricing, but, frankly, the Four Seasons is a first class hotel and the prices reflect this. IIf you want more economical options, there are many, many choices in both the Underground shopping malls and the surrounding areas.Overall, we really enjoyed our 3 nights. Service, accomodations, and location were all of the highest order. If the Four Seasons fits into your price range, you cannot go wrong.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The staff should win an award for service, kindness and professionalism. My husband and I stayed here after 4 nights of FS Singapore, 4 nights of FS Sayan Bali and 3 nights of St. Regis Bali and this was a perfect ending. This is not a resort, it's obviously a hotel in the middle of all the action, but once you walk in you're in completely peace. The staff (all of them) overly courteous, and professional. The rooms are spacious and bathrooms- top notch. There's plenty of hotels to choose from in Tokyo, but there's one standard of service and only found at the Four Seasons Tokyo! One of their staff members walked us to the bus station, which was 3 blocks away- if that tells you anything about going above and beyond. This is the reasons we only stay at the FS anytime we travel, as they always make our experience seamless.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Our family and I stayed for two nights at the Four Seasons hotel in Tokyo at Maranouchi on a trip around Asia in April. It was our first time in Japan and we were all a bit nervous about how we were going to function in a city where we not only didn't know the language, but we also had read that there were very few English street signs or maps, and that very few people spoke English. Well, our worries were unfounded. We were actually picked up at Narita airport by an FS employee called a "greeter"; a very capable lady who helped us organize our train tickets into Tokyo's main station. (Note: hiring a taxi or a private care to take you into town or to your hotel is very, very expensive. I normally don't cringe at high prices for private cars but....$900?!?! - or thereabouts?!?)The train ride was fabulous, even though we were tired. Each stop was announced in different languages including English, so we need not have worried. At the main station there was an FS employee waiting directly outside our car (everything is so well organized, it is possible for the train cars to stop in the same place every time, which is well marked on the floors of the stations). He then piled our luggage on a trolley and walked us patiently and gently through the throngs of people at the station all the way to the hotel which is next door - although you wouldn't know it because it is kind of hidden. It was a good thing he was there for us - I probably would not have found it alone. Once you are inside, everythng is an oasis of calm and order. The hotel is one of the smallest in the FS chain, only about 7 floors in total. In the traditional way of Japan, attention is paid to the slightest little detail in order to ensure perfection. Whether of beauty or technology - everything worked so well that I found myself wondering why nothing outside of Japan was so lovely, or worked so seamlessly well.Our room was amazing; it was modern, yet warm. It had a really neat sliding door that shut the sitting room off from the bedroom, and it had an awesome bathroom. And of course the super famous Japanese Toto toilets. The bathtub was gorgeous, a creamy egg shape, but I confess I found it really difficult to relax in because I kept slipping down inside it!The food was fantastic, whether Asian, Japanese or Western. The atmosphere was super-cool. All the most happening people must go there for drinks or meetings - the vibe was perfect.Room service was perfect - even a hot chocolate and cookies were presented in a faultless way. The concierge gets a special virtual hug from me for organizing who must be quite simply the best tour guide for her country ever. Miss Izumi, we all enjoyed the time you spent with us. I would recommend her services to everyone staying in Tokyo. She took us everywhere by foot, train, monorail and subway - and we saw a lot. I didn't get a chance to use the spa but I got a quick tour and it looks scrumptious - even the onsen bath looked really nice, not frightening at all for a Western visitor.We also organized tickets to Kyoto on the bullet train with the concierge, and tickets to an FC Tokyo football match. Everything went fantastically, and we are definitely coming back. BTW, the view of Mt. Fuji out the window of the bullet train to Kyoto is so incredible, if you are lucky enough to have the weather on your side to see it.Run don't walk to Tokyo - and stay here if you can afford it - it's GREAT!!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: My husband and I were at Four season in Tokyo for a short business tirp. This is not our first time in tokyo but 1st time at Four season. We love it there. The room is spacious and the service is excellent. Not mention about location, it is so convenience for us. In our free time we have use of their spa and Onsan. We would consider stay there again if we have a chance to pass by Tokyo. The price is expensive but you get what you pay for.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We stayed for three nights in mid-March and had an incredible stay. We used the meet and greet service - couldn't be easier after 16 hours of flying. FS staff member picked us up from the bus station at Tokyo Station (but left earlier than the Narita express so was more convenient) and walked us to the hotel (5 minutes or less). Check in was in the room - and an info pack containing all my restaurant reservations, shikansen tickets to Kyoto, and maps to our Ryokan there were already prepared. Everything I requested was done to perfection.We stayed in an executive suite - which is huge (2 bathrooms) and very well laid out - in a contemporary style. Beds are super comfy. WiFi and lan access are available ($20 a day) and work well. Room service breakfast was very good and showed up within 15 minutes. The room has a nespresso coffee maker as well as a french press coffee maker (excellent idea to have both!). The room had views of the trains (including the Shikansen) passing by our window (without any noise though) - which was a nice touch.When we left to Kyoto a staff member accompanied us to the train, going so fare as to help us get settled - can't beat that kind of service!All in all, you couldn't ask for more and in the competitive luxury Tokyo hotel market - the Four Seasons Marunouchi more than excels. Though there are many other good choices in Tokyo - this hotel will appeal to guests who want very personal service (with only 50 guest rooms it's an intimate a very personal experience); care for the location (very good for business and transportation - slightly less so for sightseeing); and expect the highest level of service. I also felt I got very good value for my money.
user_name:
Erik567
New York City, New York

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: My husband and I spent a week at the Four Seasons Marunouchi back in February of 2007. It was FABULOUS! First of all, they will send a Mercedes to the airport for you if you are willing to pay the $$$. This is nice if you are not familiar with Tokyo and you're jet lagged. It's a very safe place so a taxi would probably be fine, but the car is nice! The hotel has a wonderful check in system. They take you directly to your room and check you in there. No hanging in a lobby after flying for 14 hours!!! The rooms are beautiful, very modern and high end with heated floors, flat screen tv's and glass walls facing the street. Breakfast is excellent, both in the restaurant and brought to the room. The information desk is very helpful. They will get any information you might need, and will write down destination information in Japanese for you to use with cab drivers. One of the best things about the hotel is how close it is to the main train station. It is literally right next door and a hotel escort will take you to the train station and put you right on the train. They will also greet you when you return and walk you back to the hotel ( pretty confusing in the terminal...). We took the train to Nagoya and saw the 'Snow Monkeys' and to Kyoto to see the Geishas. otherwise we took a lot of taxis.The Ginza is about a 5 minute walk from the hotel and is fabulous. The shopping is amazing as are the tempura restaurants. On Sundays, they close the main street and it is full of people. You can get to the Hyatt, Harajuku district, Shinjuku etc, by train or taxi. Overall, just an amazing place. So relaxing in the middle of a hectic, huge city!!!!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I'm just back from the Fourseasons Hotel at Marunouchi in Tokyo.Everything was perfect from the beginning to the end. We arrived on February 15th in the morning after a long flight from Geneva with a stop at London-Heathrow. As our flight arrived in Tokyo at 9:15 am I ordered the room one day in advance; I did not want to be waiting untill 3 pm. The car was waiting for us at the airport and drove directly to the hotel. Our first impression was that we would have the excellence. The staff was wery welcomming; we did not have to go to the reception as the Rooms Manager was waiting for us in the lobby and immediatly introduced us the room. They had prepared a breakfast in the room; which was really appreciated.I reserved some days before a massage; they were waiting for us and we really had 90 minutes of happiness!The rooms, spa, restaurant, service are PERFECT!Yes it's an expensive hotel but you really get what you're paying for. You never have to ask thing twice. Just one exemple. We had dinner at the hotel and wanted a table in front of the windows. We had the table and they gave me at the end of the dinner an ashtree. Then we made another reservation for the end of the week; we had the same table; they remember where I sat and next to my plate they had placed an ashtree; plus they remembered I cannot eat onions and when I asked "without onions" they told me everything was planned without. This is what makes me a true Fourseasons lover. This kind of little details make all the difference; you really feel home!Really I can recommend this place to everybody. They will help you whatever you require...I'll be back!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: My partner and I stayed at the Four Seasons Hotel at Marunouchi for a week last month, and we had a fantastic time. Obviously it is an expensive hotel (and with the pound sliding against the yen whilst we were there this became increasingly clear...) but I really do feel that you get your money's worth.As this was our first time in Japan we booked the 'meet and greet' service offered by the hotel (which you pay for). This meant that we were met at the airport by a member of staff from the hotel who sorted out our bus tickets (we'd just missed the Narita Express), took us to the correct bus stop, helped with luggage, and generally made us feel very welcome after a long flight from London. She then phoned ahead to let the hotel know that we were on the bus, and someone came to meet us at the bus stop and escorted us to the hotel. We were immediately taken up to our room (a Premier King) to check-in, which again was great after a long journey. Our room was on the third floor with a lovely view across a leafy patio area and then across to Tokyo Station. If you're into that sort of thing it could be train-spotter heaven!Our room was huge with floor to ceiling windows on one side, the largest bed I think I've ever seen (it made a UK king seem tiny) and a great bathroom. This was also the first time I'd experienced a Japanese toilet, and being British it was a bit odd at first but by the end of the week I was a definite convert.The bar and restaurant (up on the 7th floor along with the spa) were great, serving some of the best cocktails I've ever had - unlike the bar in the Park Hyatt hotel where their vodka martinis tasted as if they'd been watered down.... Whilst we ate lunch and dinner elsewhere we always had breakfast in the hotel, where they did possibly the best scrambled eggs with hash browns that I've ever tasted.Finally the staff - what can I say? The other reviews here are testimony to the fact that the Four Seasons train their staff extremely well - better than any other hotel chain I can think of. You are genuinely made to feel that the hotel exists only for you - an absolute joy.I know this sounds like a gushing review, and I've honestly tried to think about some negative points to make. But all I can really comment on is the price, and as I said at the beginning I think the expense is well worth it. I hope to return soon, so I guess we'd better start saving....

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The Four Seasons Marunouchi is a boutique hotel with only 57 rooms. It’s strategically located adjacent to the Tokyo station ( the transport hub of Tokyo ) and is directly accessible by Narita Express and only a short walk away from Ginza. This is actually only the second Four Seasons that I have stayed.ArrivingI arrived by Narita Express and choose to use the “Meet and Greet” service of the hotel so that I don’t have to go thru the hassle of figuring my own way to the hotel. Things went efficiently as expected of a Four Seasons. On arriving, I was escorted to my room for in-room check. All as per expectation. Also pleasing is that the hotel has granted my request for early check-in. I arrived at 9:30AM. The RoomOK, this is a 5-star hotel no doubt and the room does reflect that. However, while it might have been cutting edge when it opened many years ago, now it’s getting long in the tooth especially compared to the newer hotels. Put plainly, this room doesn’t “ooze” luxury for the hotels of the same class. Perhaps I’m being too demanding as I have seen the very best the hotel industry has to offer. The room is basically “what you get is what you see”, ie the pictures on the website quite accurately reflect the room. I booked a “Premier Room” which is the upper tier room type in this hotel. The room measures a spacious 50+ m2 and divided into a foyer, a closet area, a bathroom, a living area and a sleeping quarters. It’s in a contemporary style but seems to be lacking some “wow” factor compared to the newer hotels like the Peninsula Tokyo. The bathroom is adequate with all the necessary stuff like advance toilet, good water pressure, deep soaking tub but otherwise is small and seems to be an after thought when designing the room. A couple using the bathroom in the morning will likely complain about the lack of space. Among some of the short comings are :-1. Small bathroom, not a full ensuite. Only one sink. 2. No LCD TV in the bathroom. In this day and age, this is almost a must. 3. No rainforest shower. Old fashion bathroom fittings in shower cubicle. 4. There is only one plasma TV facing the bed and if you choose to sit on the sofa, it’s position such that you can’t watch the TV at the same time. Putting up another TV or using a rotating cabinet would be helpful5. There’s no wireless internet in the room or at least I couldn’t find it. 6. Very small electronic safe. Can hardly put anything larger than a passport.  7. Bed is run-of-the-mill, not as comfortable as the best I have slept in. 8. Lack of power plugs on the desk ( only one! ). I need to request an extension from housekeeping, then adapters. Given the spacious work desk, why don’t they incorporate more plugs into the wall?9. View facing train station and Tokyo Forum wasn’t very impressiveThere are some good points though. The room is very quiet, evident by the triple glazing employed. Some good gadgets including iPod dock ( with remote ), a Bose CD/Alarm clock ( but with awful sound ), plasma TV etc. Common AreasThis hotel is really small. It’s inside a office tower. If you don’t pay attention, you can easily miss the entrance. There’s only one restaurant which also function as a bar and a lounge and the prices are astronomically expensive ( USD40++ for a set breakfast with only standard items ). The lobby is very small, with the reception and concierge desk taking up most of the space. However, the common areas are tastefully decorated. Basically, it’s a very small hotel, really boutique in that sense. ServiceNothing to fault here though as a boutique hotel, service can be over-bearing at times. Everywhere I go, the staff seems to know who I am and greet me by name. They also rush to help with pressing the lift, carrying bags etc. Not that it’s a bad thing of course. Also as expected of a Four Seasons, the rooms are kept impeccably clean. To be very fair, I have to say the Four Seasons service level is so far the best I have seen in Tokyo and almost comparable to the Excellent Four Seasons Hong Kong. Value This hotel is incredibly expensive, commanding top tier rate among 5-star luxury hotels in Tokyo and therein lies the problem. I happened to book a weekend rate which is about Yen10,000 cheaper ( and that’s excluding breakfast and no benefits of any kind ). Yet, for the price, the room quality is obviously inferior even when compared to the newer Ritz Carlton, not to mention the far more extravagant Peninsula Tokyo. It’s almost embarrassingly inadequate. Really, a renovation is by now overdue if the Four Seasons Marunouchi intends to position itself as a premium luxury hotel. There’s also no amazing view to speak of too as the hotel is a low rise. The only area that the hotel delivers is in service, but then this is Tokyo, good service is almost always expected, plus or minus some.  ConclusionOverall, this hotel is “OK” but I’m not particularly impressed by it, especially the room quality. I did not have high expectations for this hotel in the beginning and just thought of trying something new. So I was quite pleased to have only tried out one night and happily moved over to the Peninsula the following day. I would say it’s a good choice if you want a 5-star hotel that’s near to Ginza and also appreciate to have the constant attention of the hotel staff. However, unless the room rates can be significantly lower or that the owners invested in renovation to enhance the room quality and amenities, I doubt I will return as the Peninsula is a substantially more attractive alternative.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We arrived into Tokyo for the start of our business trip... without luggage... (so the story begins).We ordered the "Meet and Greet" service at the airport, a lovely woman (who waited almost an hour while we were dealing with our luggage, which was still somewhere in Europe), guided us to the train and even arranged for the hotel to provide us with a private car (and driver) to take us shopping ... so we would have suitable attire for our business meetings the next day.When we arrived into Tokyo Station (taking the ever so convenient Narita Express), a Four Seasons rep met us on the platform, precisely at our car (which is called ahead by the airport greeter), who guided us through the station maze to the hotel. The hotel: Stunning! Comfortable beyond explanation. No toiletry was missing (which was most appreciated, since we had almost nothing in our hand luggage). The lobby is on the 7th floor and affords excellent views. The staff: We arrived with only one hour left to shop for business clothes; our stretch 7-series BMW car with white-glove-wearing driver awaiting our arrival. We were whisked away to a Ginza dept. store; the driver waited patiently in front... we were astounded at this level of service! Not only did each member of the staff graciously accommodate our requests, they diligently chased up our luggage (communicating regularly with the airport) to ensure that everything arrived as soon as possible (we had to take a Shinkasen to Osaka the evening after our arrival). We can't thank everyone enough for taking such good care of us after a long flight, in our exhausted state.Admittedly, we were a bit rushed and could not enjoy the hotel facilities (restaurant, gym) as we wished, but the room was luxurious - and the large bathtub (complete with aromatic bath salts) was divine. We can't imagine staying anywhere else in Tokyo: the staff, the property, the location - all perfect!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We loved our stay here. We were in Japan for 1 week. From the advice of another trip advisor i booked the meet and greet service from the Four Seasons to collect us from customs , take us to get our JR passes and put us on the right train. From there we were met at Tokyo station and taken to the hotel for the easiest and swiftest check in ever. We had our first night here before we went off for travels to Kyoto and Hakone for a few days before coming back to the Four Seasons for 2 more nights.The service was excellent, the concierge sent us to some fab restaurants. We ate in the hotel on our last night and it was excellent. The staff at the Four Seasons made our trip so easy and were so helpful.The rooms were excellent and when we came back we had been upgraded so it was even better.I chose this hotel as it is a great base if you are planning to use the trains,,,also it is the Four Seasons!!!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We stayed in Tokyo en route to Bali Indonesia, this was our second vacation back to Bali and decided to enjoy a week in Tokyo.Stayed at the Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi, this best of all the worlds, because it's Elegance Boutique meets Elegant Four Seasons, this is WHAT A HOTEL should be!The staff is beyond outstanding, we got confused regarding the international timeline, so upon arrival we were one day late, I was horrified thought we lost the hotel and $$. This hotel was so nice, they did not penalize us for this mistake, kept our room! Also, a little secret; there are Bianchi bicycles that you can loan out I highly recommend this was a fabulous way to see Tokyo up close and personal. We dont' speak any Japanese, but people were extremely nice. Visited the Imperial Palace via bicycles, got interviewed by a famous Radio Personality, saw the Royal Family, the empress waived at us.The restaurant at the Four Seasons was fantastic! and must have a elegant cocktails in the lounge.The location is so wonderful, close to the Train Station, excellent shopping in Ginza District.Highly recommended! Will return again...

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We have stayed at the Marunouchi on a few occasions and each time in a different type of room. The standard room was very nice, if a little small, with a windowless large bathroom. We have also stayed in one bedroom suites with a city view and a view of the station. The suites were large and exquisite with some unique features. While the station view is gorgeous, it is a little noisy. Business travellers and sensitive sleepers are probably best to ask for a city view room.The hotel is very well located. Tokyo Station, Ginza, the Imperial Palace and the Forum are within walking distance. All the sites are easily accessible by train which makes the proximity to Tokyo Station desirable (unlike the Park Hyatt which is 10 minute drive from the the closest station).The in-room electronics and amenities are excellent. LIke many other Four Seasons, the hotel provides L'Occitane bathproducts but also provides Kniepp bath salts and pillows. Yukatas and pj's can also be found in the room (in addition to the usual bathrobe) which adds a unique Japanese touch. A variety of pillows are available upon request. HIgh quality Japanese green tea and coffee are available in the room (along with china, an electric tea kettle and a french press).The hotel is very small (57 rooms). The entire staff greets you by name. The staff also notes preferences and ensures they are observed on follow-up visits. For example, we once requested an iron and on subsequent visits an iron has been placed in our room. The hotel is generally very quiet which makes it an excellent hotel for business travel.The spa is small but the onsen and gym are wonderful.The food is very expensive, even by Tokyo and Four Seasons standards. For example, a soft drink is 1000 yen. The same soft drink is available at the nearby convenience store for 140 yen. The price of the food seemed quite excessive. The cost of in-room movies was also very high (2000 yen).The concierge service was a bit mixed but generally excellent. In some respects they are very organized and go out of thier way to be helpful. On one visit, we had a Japan Rail Pass and planned to travel the country. The hotel sent a staff member to get tickets for every leg of our trip at no cost. As we were taking a small bag on our trip, they allowed us to store our luggage while touring the country and pick it up before leaving Tokyo (at no cost). This was very helpful to us and we appreciated the hotel did not charge us for these services. As well, print-outs are available for all major sites that provide a description of the site, colour pictures and a map. The concierge is also very good about making reservations, getting good tables etc... but they don't always check pertinent information before giving advice. For example, on two occassions we were told a tourist site was open and on both occasions the sites were closed (one was a regular closing and the other owing to a national holiday). I would advise people to ask the concierge to verify if the particular destination is open at the time they would like to visit. On the whole, we were very pleased with the hotel and returned after our first visit. We will stay at this property on our next trip to Tokyo.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I stayed in a corner room that had ceiling to floor windows on two walls and views of the famous lighted street in Ginza. It was spectacular at night. The rooms are contemporary and comfortable with electronic shades, lights and original artwork. There are great down comforters and superior linens on the beds. I loved the in room tea service with several authentic Japanese tea selections. Bathrobes provided were light and comfortable. The bathroom was modern and sleek with a great bathtub set between the tricked out toilet (with heated seat and other fun features) and the shower. The towel rack was heated! The room service was a tad slow but the stuffed french toast was so good that I still think about it. The in room internet service was annoying, as it was hard to maneuver the mouse and took a long time to load. The maid service was constant and one walked in on me while I was in a state of undress. The spa is just a couple of uninviting rooms with no amenities, although the massage was divine. The hotel is located on a couple of floors in a high rise building and does not have many rooms. Asking for directions and recommendations for dining was not easy. They kept sending us to restaurants designed for tourists. It is very expensive and very exclusive. It is unique considering that it is in a huge building yet retains a feeling of intimacy and beauty. The doorman always greeted me by name with a bow. They provide free pastries and coffee in the lobby in the early am (4-6) which is great if you are heading out to the fish market and need a wake up coffee. It is something to experience at least once in a lifetime. I was equally pleased with the Mandarin Oriental which was half the price and liked the rooms and spa better; although the personal service was not at the same level. You will feel like royalty while at the Four Seasons and may possibly become too accustomed to privilege for your own good. Enjoy!

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: This is a very beautiful hotel in a superb location. Ours was a standard room on the 3rd floor. Check-in was effortless. The room was huge and gorgeous. It was also very quiet despite facing a major street. The bathroom was very large--larger than our bathroom at the Shinjuku Park Hyatt, but unlike our room at the Hyatt, there was no window in the bathroom. It was hardly a big deal, though, considering how luxurious it was. We had dinner at the Ekki Bar and Grill one night. The restaurant is beautifully decorated and the atmosphere was quiet and elegant. The service was not quick but well-paced to allow us to linger over wine and to chat. The food was first class.We had a few problems with the service, though. One morning the waiter forgot to put in our breakfast order so we had to wait over 45 minutes after ordering to get our food. There were only about 5 other tables at the time, so it was hardly busy. The next morning, the wait staff apologized. The servings of the 'breakfast entrees' were far too large, but the food was delicious. Everything was fresh and beautifully presented. The next morning the waitress forgot my coffee and I didn't get it until I was almost finished eating, despite asking for it twice. Also, housekeeping took my nightshirt -- the only thing I had brought to sleep in -- out with the linens when they changed the room. The shirt was returned the next day with a card from the housekeeping manager containing an apology along with some chocolates. The front desk staff, though, were knowledgable, friendly, and very professional.The location is hard to beat. It's within easy walking distance of three metro stops, Ginza, the Marunouchi Building, and the Imperial Palace.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I have traveled the world and stayed in many 5 star hotels and I can tell you hands down, there is not another hotel that compares to the level of service you will receive here.The fact that there are only 57 rooms is a major advantage for any guest who stays here.We chose to your the greeting service at Narita airport. The service greeted us right outside customs, proceeded to the train ticket counter and purchased our Narita Express train ticket and took us right to our seat. We were assured that when the train door opens at Tokyo Station a Four Seasons Concierge will be waiting for us, and they were. We were quickly whisked through the huge terminal to the hotel.As we entered the hotel there were 5 people at the door greeting us. A reception attendant greeted us by name and stated that they had been looking forward to our arrival. He then took us right to our room and completed the check in process in our room. He stated that it was the hotels pleasure to upgrade us.We were given a room that about took our breath away when the door opened. The interior design is the most amazing mixture of exotic wood walls, black bamboo flooring, leather headboard and ceiling panels on the bed, curved round walls that end into 180 degree view that are comprised of floor to ceiling glass.The bathroom is beyond beatiful. The glass bowl sinkls, glass shower and toilet walls are very nice. The egg shaped bath tub is one of the most unique tubs I've ever seen.There are original pieces of art in the room as well as sculpted pieces of art on pedastals.The concierge staff is extremely eager to help and navigated a path for us to see the city with pure ease.This hotel is extremely pricey. However, if you are looking for 5 star service like no place you have ever experienced, this is your hotel.I'll post photo's in the next week.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The Four Seasons at Marunouchi is strategically located at walking distance from the Tokyo Station (2 min) and Ginza Fashion district (5 min). It is actually a small hotel, different from the Four Seasons you may expect. The hotel is very stylish -above all the lobbies and the Spa- rooms are modern and spacious, with very comfortable bathroom (with shower and tub). Our room (#501) had a very nice view of the conference center. The room amenities are very complete (included pyjamas and gowns replaced daily). What I appreciated most in the Hotel was the amazing courtesy, kindness, punctuality and availability of the hotel staff (...really "beyond compare"), probably the best hotel service I ever experienced. If compared with the Park Hyatt where I stayed later, the four seasons is probably more elegant, and it is definitely in a better neighborhood (but more expensive too). The only disappointment is about the breakfast: it is only served a la carte, it is expensive and the service is too slow for breakfast time.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The Marunouchi Four Seasons is an experience which we rated one of the finest in the World.Never in all of our travels have we experienced better personalized , heartfelt service from the Management, front desk, baggage help and restaurant team.You are warmlygreeted by staff at the door and esorted and check in, in your room. After a long trip this is a welcome benefit.They have a special service to pick you up from your plane and get you to the right train to Tokyo or anyother place you are going by train.The concerige succeeded to book us into Ryokan that we had tried in vain to achieve in the USA even with all the help of our well connected Japanese friends.Food at the restaurant was a surprise and a 5 Star Napa experience with a visiting chef from California who 's menu was a delight to the senses.Everything from the small details of the luxury soaps in the bath to the comfortable beds and quiet rooms to the in room dining service impressed us and we will return again.This hotel is like a country retreat in the middle of the City.We love trains this is the place to view the Bullet Trains of Japan from your window as they float in to Tokyo Station without a sound to disturb your breakfast.This is the perfect Boutique Hotel Experience and we shall return again. R&M G

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: It is rare that my husband and two sons and I all agree on a hotel. But this hotel is really exceptional and we all loved it. The rooms (and we had two) are magnificently equipped and furnished in a modern, sleek style. I have never seen so many useful little items in a hotel room: pajamas, hairbrush, rubber bands for hair, oil blotting papers for the face, toothbrush and paste, beautiful pens. The bathroom toiletries were all in a very substantial size too, instead of the tiny little bottles you usually get. The beds were sublimely comfortable. We loved the room.Other nice features of the hotel are a fabulously equipped gym, and free internet access for guests. Granted, there is only one computer available for use, but we never found getting online to be a problem. The location of the hotel is great. It's an easy walk to the Ginza for shopping, and the hotel is right next to Tokyo Station. In fact, many of the rooms at the hotel have a view of the bullet trains as they go in and out of Tokyo Station. We loved watching the trains - but our room was not overlooking them too closely...We had breakfast included with our rooms. The restaurant is really beautifully decorated, and is a relaxing place to dine. We didn't find the breakfast menu to be too inspiring, however. We coudn't really find anything that we enjoyed eating. The American breakfast was sub-standard - bacon and sausage were not tasty, and the eggs so-so. One day my son ordered waffles, and it consisted of one tiny waffle cut in half...We are not huge eaters, but the portions were quite small. The lattes were tasty, but quite weak. So, while we usually enjoy breakfast in our hotel, this was definitely not one of our favorites.Generally, we were very pleased with the service. The staff could not have been friendlier or more gracious. We did have a small problem with the concierge. They booked tickets for us on the bullet train to Kyoto. We were told the tickets would cost about $400 - but the concierge didn't mention that this was EACH WAY. So, it was a bit of a surprise when we finally got the bill for $800. Well, no place is perfect, but this hotel is really quite close...We would definitely return...

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Many problems with our stay - we moved to a better hotel (see Palace Hotel - not a posh as Four Seasons but service wasmuch better). Arrived at Four Seasons with a friend and her young son and explained that we wanted a suite so that they could stay the night wiht us. Reception messed up our reservation, and sent us up to a room where a guest was already staying. Embarrassing to walk into someone else's room when they are still there!!! Then when we asked for extra blankets and pillows, the hotel wanted to charge us $50/pers extra (for my friend and her son) on top of the rate they were already charging us for the suite. The five-year-old was so upset, and told my husband that he didn't need to stay the night if it was a problem. Another problem - the concierge sent us to a restaurant that was having a private party. I would think that they would call ahead before blindly recommending places...

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: In a totally different league from any other hotel in Tokyo.Simply -- amazing.Again, it is literally in a different league, a different category, to the other well-known hotels in Tokyo.Enjoy.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Can't rave enough about this hotel. Travelled with 4 children plus babysitter. Rooms very big for Tokyo with nice views (we were on the 4th floor -- corner room in particular is very nice) -- we had a connecting room with huge full size bed in one room; twins plus crib in the other. But the rave is about the service. Our minibus from the airport was greeted by several staff with our check-in folio in hand, everyone knew our name every time we came in or out of the hotel, bellmen (and women) were instantaneous, courteous, friendly; same with front desk and restaurant. When we arrived at the room, there were robes in sizes for each person (including kids) and cookies and marshmallows with their names waiting on the counter. Only negative are the prices in the restaurant (hotel has only one restaurant, and juice is $12.00 for a modest glass-- don't let the kids order refills! - an American breakfast around $30.00). As an alternative check out the trainstation across the street. There are lots of nice bakeries, japanese restaurants, and even a mcdonald's and a starbucks for those feeling homesick. The stairs down are probably 100 feet from the hotel entrance. The location is superb not just because of the trainstation, but because the Ginza district is very close by and there is lots of great shopping, department stores, cafes (outdoor and indoor) and sights within a short distance. Particularly fun was the fish market - where the tuna auction at around 6 AM was fascinating for everyone and the hour was fine for us jet laggers

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We stayed at the Marunouchi Four Seasons for 5 days while on vacation in Japan. The accommodations are out of this world - best bedding, toiletries, amenities and service I've ever experienced. The greatest find of all was the 'bed & breakfast' package which we did not originally book but added to our profile after the first night. For an extra Y1000 (approximately, US $9) per day, we added the breakfast option to the room. The menu was exceptional - the choices unlimited - and the satisfaction to this highly picky eater was great. We received excellent service from the whole staff - bellboys to the coincerge - and only wish there was more time to lounge about Tokyo so that we could have enjoyed the experience even longer. On our last day, the hotel booked the train tickets to Narita Airport and had one of their staff take our bags directly to the platform for depature. It was great, and we would definitely recommend this property to others - the price is actually quite reasonable for the most expensive city in the world! - and you can't get a better location than this...

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: Just a block away from Tokyo station, the entrance to this small Four Seasons is tucked away on the side of a non-descript glass and steel building. However, the service and accomodations are anything but non-descript.   An extremely gracious staff member who spoke perfect english met us right in our train car as it came to a stop in Tokyo station. He escorted us quickly up out of the station and over to a waiting car. Although the hotel is within walking distance, and they normally walk guests over, he saw that my wife was pregnant and quickly called ahead for a car to meet us. Once inside the hotel, we were greeted by another extremely gracious staff member who lead us immediately up to a beautiful and spacious room on the 5th floor with an enormous glass wall overlooking the street scene below. He quickly showed us the room, took care of a few details, and then got out of our hair after giving us his personal business card in case we needed anything at all. The room felt very large and was very tastefully decorated, the king bed was the most comfortable I've ever slept in. We remarked that *this* is what Westin's "heavenly bed" should be like. The eligant granite and brass bathroom was huge, and had gorgeous frosted glass walls seperating the toilet, shower, and closet areas. The walls of the rooms in the hotel have obviously been sound proofed, as the room was absolutely dead silent. We never heard a peep from anything outside our room. On our return to Tokyo a week later, we stayed again at the Four Seasons. We were met this time by the same staff member at the door, who did away completely with the check in procedure and led us up to a new room, as they had upgraded us this time to a suite. The suite had a seperate bedroom and living room which made it feel not quite as spacious as the first room we'd staying in, however it was just as lovely and had a second toilet room by the door, which could useful in a business situation. This room was on the side of the building, which as another reviewer noted, meant you could here the trains going past. However, it was extremely muted and I found it actually pleasant to listen to. Unless you've got a specific issue with trains, I can't see how it would bother anybody. The next morning we departed Tokyo, and the concierge had purchased our train tickets for us, we were again led to our train where the porter waited with us for twenty minutes and helped load our bags onto the train, and then again met at our train as it arrived at the airport and taken to the check in counter. Top class service. Top class rooms. Simply a fantastic experience all around.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I stayed 7 nights in a deluxe premier room. I'ts a very big room with a 42 inc plasma tv and a wonderful marble bath. Service at FS is perfect, everyone is there for you, i was on a leisure trip and they assisted me all the time, also booking for me bullet train ticket to kyoto. Maybe the view on the trains tracks is not the maximum if you don't like trains! anyway i suggest it also for Ginza location.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I have repeatedly stayed at many of Tokyo's top hotels, including the Park Hyatt (which, until this trip, was my favoured choice). But the service at the FS is unbelievable, even by Japanese standards, and easily trumps what I have experienced at the PHT, the Grand Hyatt (even with Diamond status) and others in the course of multiple stays. The Ginza location is also very convenient for business and personal travel. I would not stay anywhere else in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: It is the best hotel I have ever seen ! The service and the rooms are incredible ! The doorman even used our name when we came in for the first time (I still don't understand how he did it !). We had a room facing the train tracks, but we haven't heard the trains and it is quite fun actually to see the trains that close without hearing anything.Location is perfect. Centrally located.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: I stayed at this hotel for three nights during Christmas season. It was a bit different Four Seasons experience. Although there was so many hotel employees, none of them seem to have trained good enough to welcome those people who are paying for five star hotel.For discounted rate or corporate rate, you will be assigned the room facing Tokyo station. This is terrible as you will hear consistent noise of trains passing by for almost 24 hours. The room itself is quite nicely decorated and very sapcious especially for hotel in Tokyo. The bathroom is just huge and quite realxing. However, you may feel squeezy from low ceiling. The fact that it is close to Tokyo station means it is a bit far from any other places in Tokyo. The Chinzanso one is a lot more like any other Four Seasons. I would not probably go back next time.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: The Four Seasons Marunouchi is the best hotel I have ever stayed at. The level of service and accommodation is outstanding and every single member of staff seems genuinely keen to help. The hotel is located very close to Tokyo station, which makes it very easy to reach if you fly to Narita airport (the hotel will even arrange to meet you at the station (at no charge) if you want). It is also extremely well located for the Imperial Palace and the Ginza District.I have just returned from a the round the world trip during which time I have been fortunate to stay at some excellent 5 star hotels, howver the Marunouchi is definitley in a league of its own and I will be going back as soon as I can.

hotel_name: Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi
review_body: We had the pleasure of 10 days here and the service, food, room, location, cleaning etc. is superb. This is by far the best four seasons I have ever experienced. The location is amazing- about one block to tokyo station. From there, you can get anywhere. The staff, oh my God, they were above and beyond anything I have ever experienced. When we checked out, they all lined up to say goodbye like fantasy island or something, it was kind of weird, but fun. The concierges are great, but one was so outstanding, we actually bought him a gift when we left. It is beyond professionalism. I have never had such amazing breakfasts in my life. Room service was also incredible/perfection. The bathroom was great. Their spa was fantastic- they have an onsen there and it is just lovely. They give you gym clothes if you want to work out. The actual architecture could not be more cool, and the building is connected to Paul, from France, for the best pastries ever. We still talk about it and will be back! No better place in Tokyo.
